description: Over 80% of computers run Microsoft Operating systems. As a result, the Microsoft Certified Solutions Associate is one of the first steps for those seeking to start a technical career. The 70-697 Configuring Windows Devices exam covers topics that are a “must know” for anyone responsible for deploying, maintaining and supporting Windows desktops and other devices in a corporate or enterprise environment. Most people know how to use Windows in a home environment, but there are many features under the hood that are designed for environments with a large quantity of computers. The MCSA dives into those and gives the viewer a whole new toolbox for ensuring their computing environment is functional and stable.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie show that Windows 10 is still capable of integrating with existing authentication providers.  Windows 10 still can carry out username/password authentication using the credential manager, local accounts as well domain accounts.  They also show how to configure Windows Hello for authentication.

00:28:05.291 --> 00:28:07.280
Click Next, and there it goes.

558
00:28:07.280 --> 00:28:09.420
It actually is gonna say, hey,
are you sure you want to do this?

559
00:28:09.420 --> 00:28:11.077
You wanna move everything over there?

560
00:28:11.077 --> 00:28:15.337
Sure thing, I go ahead and click Finish,
and now it's gonna take the sweet time

561
00:28:15.337 --> 00:28:18.532
it's gonna take to perform that
move over to that machine.

562
00:28:18.532 --> 00:28:20.456
And as long as your machine, or

563
00:28:20.456 --> 00:28:23.712
your Hyper-V console manager
can find that again,

564
00:28:23.712 --> 00:28:29.230
it should now be ready to go and ready to
operate and do everything that we need to.

565
00:28:29.230 --> 00:28:33.190
So it really is very nice,
because if not, you do have to go in and

566
00:28:33.190 --> 00:28:34.800
find all those little pieces.

567
00:28:34.800 --> 00:28:37.230
Look, let's just make a wizard,
we'll make it easier for

568
00:28:37.230 --> 00:28:39.230
most people that are using client Hyper-V.

569
00:28:39.230 --> 00:28:40.305
The reason that they do that, right?

570
00:28:40.305 --> 00:28:42.850
Cuz you're probably saying,
why would I ever do that?

571
00:28:42.850 --> 00:28:46.900
Well, what if you are making a test server
and now that test server, you're saying,

572
00:28:46.900 --> 00:28:49.460
look, this is what we really want to use.

573
00:28:49.460 --> 00:28:51.460
Well, you have two choices right?

574
00:28:51.460 --> 00:28:55.430
You can say, now I can go to my actual
Hyper-V server on my network and

575
00:28:55.430 --> 00:28:57.290
rebuild the whole thing again.

576
00:28:57.290 --> 00:28:59.560
Put all the configurations in,
do everything.

577
00:28:59.560 --> 00:29:01.660
But if your machine's already operating,

578
00:29:01.660 --> 00:29:07.070
why not simply move this machine over
to the production network instead.

579
00:29:07.070 --> 00:29:08.359
Verify it's working.

580
00:29:08.359 --> 00:29:11.609
That's also why we might
use client Hyper-V as well.

581
00:29:11.609 --> 00:29:15.750
To get things ready without really
impacting our server's performance even on

582
00:29:15.750 --> 00:29:17.520
the network at this point.

583
00:29:17.520 --> 00:29:19.023
So it's a good test machine.

584
00:29:19.023 --> 00:29:22.030
It can help you in preparation for
production machines as well.

585
00:29:22.030 --> 00:29:23.160
>> It sure can.

586
00:29:23.160 --> 00:29:26.457
Now Hyper-V we've obviously talked
a lot about Hyper-V but guess what?

587
00:29:26.457 --> 00:29:29.685
We finally have come to the end
of what Hyper-V can do, or

588
00:29:29.685 --> 00:29:33.470
at least what you need to know for
the exam to understand Hyper-V.

589
00:29:33.470 --> 00:29:35.698
Ronnie, anything else
that we need to go over?

590
00:29:35.698 --> 00:29:38.024
I'm looking at the notes,
I think we've covered it all, but

591
00:29:38.024 --> 00:29:40.679
is there any tidbits of wisdom you
wanna leave these good people with?

592
00:29:40.679 --> 00:29:42.959
>> Try it, is pretty much the key here.

593
00:29:42.959 --> 00:29:45.535
There is no harm in you
building virtual machines, and

594
00:29:45.535 --> 00:29:47.220
the nice thing about them, right.

595
00:29:47.220 --> 00:29:49.901
Is if you use them and you tear them up.

596
00:29:49.901 --> 00:29:50.598
It's simple.

597
00:29:50.598 --> 00:29:54.585
Delete the file, try it again, you don't
have to worry about a lot of extra

598
00:29:54.585 --> 00:29:57.900
hardware being taken up,
just make sure you keep an eye on it.

599
00:29:57.900 --> 00:30:00.640
So follow good sets, right?

600
00:30:00.640 --> 00:30:04.829
Don't put so many virtual machines on your
machine at one time, if you only have like

601
00:30:04.829 --> 00:30:07.846
let say four or eight gigs of RAM and
try and start them all up.

602
00:30:07.846 --> 00:30:10.563
The good thing is it will tell you,
you don't have enough resources to do so.

603
00:30:10.563 --> 00:30:15.369
But at the same time try, to remember
that you can overload that one machine.

604
00:30:15.369 --> 00:30:18.171
And even though we don't tend
to use it up a lot of the times,

605
00:30:18.171 --> 00:30:21.661
those virtual machines, they will
eat up your processors after awhile.

606
00:30:21.661 --> 00:30:24.796
So make sure you also keep an eye
on the performance of your machine,

607
00:30:24.796 --> 00:30:25.898
you'll be ready to go.

608
00:30:25.898 --> 00:30:26.665
>> Awesome stuff.

609
00:30:26.665 --> 00:30:29.265
All right everyone that comes to
the end of another great episode.

610
00:30:29.265 --> 00:30:30.379
Hopefully you've enjoyed it.

611
00:30:30.379 --> 00:30:32.644
We're going to go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

612
00:30:32.644 --> 00:30:33.978
I've been your host, Daniel Lowry.

613
00:30:33.978 --> 00:30:34.768
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

614
00:30:34.768 --> 00:30:36.347
>> And we'll see you next time.

615
00:30:36.347 --> 00:30:42.830
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie configure some of the different options that allow access to files when offline and even the ability to take Windows 10 with you wherever you go.
episodes.title: Mobility Options
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.611 --> 00:00:12.820
All right.

3
00:00:12.820 --> 00:00:16.590
Greetings everyone, and welcome to
another great episode of ITPro TV.

4
00:00:16.590 --> 00:00:20.180
I'm your host Daniel Lawrie, here with me
today, none other than Mr. Ronnie Wong.

5
00:00:20.180 --> 00:00:20.970
How's it going Ronnie?

6
00:00:20.970 --> 00:00:22.180
>> It is going well today.

7
00:00:22.180 --> 00:00:26.840
As we continue on taking a look at
configuring Windows 10 devices,

8
00:00:26.840 --> 00:00:29.590
we want to make sure that we understand
that there are actually a lot of different

9
00:00:29.590 --> 00:00:32.790
devices that are out there that
Windows 10 are designed to work with.

10
00:00:32.790 --> 00:00:34.220
Not only things like laptops, but

11
00:00:34.220 --> 00:00:37.840
of course there are tablets that are out
there, and then the, hopefully in

12
00:00:37.840 --> 00:00:41.390
the future the upcoming Windows phones
that should also support Windows 10.

13
00:00:41.390 --> 00:00:44.610
But there’s a lot of these devices and
because of that,

14
00:00:44.610 --> 00:00:47.330
it also means that we have to be
used to configuring some of the of

15
00:00:47.330 --> 00:00:51.795
the mobility options that we tend to find
being able to work inside of Windows 10.

16
00:00:51.795 --> 00:00:56.005
Now for us to do that, of course it means
a combination of several things and

17
00:00:56.005 --> 00:00:58.255
getting access into the operating system,
and

18
00:00:58.255 --> 00:01:01.505
understanding what we find there is
actually going to be very important,

19
00:01:01.505 --> 00:01:05.295
because the goal is fairly simple for
what Windows really wants you to do.

20
00:01:05.295 --> 00:01:08.565
They want you to be united behind
a single operating system,

21
00:01:08.565 --> 00:01:10.215
regardless of the device that you're on.

22
00:01:10.215 --> 00:01:13.710
And so if Windows 10 is going to be that,
you also have to be able to work

23
00:01:13.710 --> 00:01:16.910
with some of the ways that we
used to deal with desktop files,

24
00:01:16.910 --> 00:01:20.090
as well as some of the other options
that you have available to you.

25
00:01:20.090 --> 00:01:23.860
You might even find out that you're trying
to run on Windows 10, but you might end up

26
00:01:23.860 --> 00:01:27.540
at a company or someplace else in which
you don't have access to Windows 10.

27
00:01:27.540 --> 00:01:30.220
Is there a way that you can
still take Windows 10 with you?

28
00:01:30.220 --> 00:01:31.310
Yes there is, and

29
00:01:31.310 --> 00:01:34.610
we'll also show you the idea that
we'll call Windows to Go as well.

30
00:01:34.610 --> 00:01:38.130
And then we also want to be able to
configure some security settings

31
00:01:38.130 --> 00:01:40.070
on our mobile devices As well, and

32
00:01:40.070 --> 00:01:42.660
we are specifically referring
to BitLocker at this point.

33
00:01:42.660 --> 00:01:47.270
There's a lot for us to cover when we take
a look at the different mobility options

34
00:01:47.270 --> 00:01:49.580
that we have available to us.

35
00:01:49.580 --> 00:01:54.900
When it comes down to dealing with files,
one of the hardest things that we

36
00:01:54.900 --> 00:01:59.350
have to kind of deal with is the very fact
that most of us inside of an enterprise.

37
00:01:59.350 --> 00:02:03.560
What's going to happen is we are privately
accessing some type of network file share,

38
00:02:03.560 --> 00:02:06.530
and when that ends up happening,
a lot of times what we end up with,

39
00:02:06.530 --> 00:02:09.380
of course, is that we connect
to a map network drive, or

40
00:02:09.380 --> 00:02:12.330
we just go ahead and
we do our regular type of

41
00:02:12.330 --> 00:02:15.980
connection where it's just a temporary
connection by using our backslash,

42
00:02:15.980 --> 00:02:19.070
backslash, the name of the server, and
then the name of that shared folder.

43
00:02:19.070 --> 00:02:23.140
And we gain access to it, or we might map
it to our computers as a drive letter, and

44
00:02:23.140 --> 00:02:25.870
that's perfectly fine
that we do something.

45
00:02:25.870 --> 00:02:28.870
But the problem happens to be,
especially if you are on a laptop,

46
00:02:28.870 --> 00:02:32.610
right, is when you take that laptop home,
and all of a sudden,

47
00:02:32.610 --> 00:02:36.860
you don't have access to those network
files anymore, and so now you're kind of

48
00:02:36.860 --> 00:02:40.365
stuck, even though you were actually
able to get access to them at one point.

49
00:02:40.365 --> 00:02:43.335
Now you're at home, or you're
actually away on a business trip, and

50
00:02:43.335 --> 00:02:46.225
those files just don't seem
to be available to you.

51
00:02:46.225 --> 00:02:48.565
Well, when something like that happens,
what can you do?

52
00:02:48.565 --> 00:02:53.083
Well in today's world, there's really
a lot that you can do because of

53
00:02:53.083 --> 00:02:57.980
the overwhelming popularity and the
ubiquity of things like VPN access, and

54
00:02:57.980 --> 00:03:02.724
because we're really no longer having
to depend on dial up connections and

55
00:03:02.724 --> 00:03:04.860
the cost of dial up connections.

56
00:03:04.860 --> 00:03:09.454
Creating a VPN connection back to our
servers when we need to is probably

57
00:03:09.454 --> 00:03:10.457
not a bad idea.

58
00:03:10.457 --> 00:03:14.516
It's probably something that we can
actually do and all that can be configured

59
00:03:14.516 --> 00:03:18.880
in the background, but there's other
times that you may not have any access.

60
00:03:18.880 --> 00:03:21.950
What if you don't have access
to a network connection or

61
00:03:21.950 --> 00:03:25.650
what if you're actually out there and
there is no internet connection at all?

62
00:03:25.650 --> 00:03:27.270
But what can you do instead?

63
00:03:27.270 --> 00:03:31.130
Microsoft still likes the idea
of what we call off-line files.

64
00:03:31.130 --> 00:03:34.320
So when we talk about actually
using off-line files,

65
00:03:34.320 --> 00:03:38.370
what we're actually saying is that
we're going to kind of lie to you.

66
00:03:38.370 --> 00:03:40.540
That's the easiest way I
know how to think about it.

67
00:03:40.540 --> 00:03:41.960
Is that it's really lying to you.

68
00:03:41.960 --> 00:03:45.454
You're going to make the same network
connection as you would if you were logged

69
00:03:45.454 --> 00:03:49.054
into a computer, and once you do something
like that, what can also happen is once

70
00:03:49.054 --> 00:03:52.287
you've got them configured the way
that you want to, well even if you're

71
00:03:52.287 --> 00:03:56.200
disconnected from the network,
it still looks like you're connected here.

72
00:03:56.200 --> 00:03:59.400
So let me go ahead and do that here.

73
00:03:59.400 --> 00:04:03.390
I just kind of realized something,
I had launched up my wrong machine here.

74
00:04:03.390 --> 00:04:07.670
Let me change that configuration for
just a moment as we get started.

75
00:04:07.670 --> 00:04:11.450
And we'll show you kind of the basic
configurations that we need to go through

76
00:04:11.450 --> 00:04:15.700
to make sure that everything is actually
going to work out the way we want.

77
00:04:15.700 --> 00:04:20.060
If I can actually get my virtual
machine running the way that I need to.

78
00:04:20.060 --> 00:04:22.180
Let me launch up the bird one here.

79
00:04:22.180 --> 00:04:23.980
This is the one that's actually
connected to the network.

80
00:04:25.110 --> 00:04:28.220
And then we'll bring that one up and
we'll be ready to go here.

81
00:04:28.220 --> 00:04:30.820
So what we're going to do is we're going
to show you how we would normally connect

82
00:04:30.820 --> 00:04:34.590
to a network file share, and then we're
going to show you how to take it offline,

83
00:04:34.590 --> 00:04:38.540
and that way you can actually see where
those files are going to be available, and

84
00:04:38.540 --> 00:04:39.160
that way,

85
00:04:39.160 --> 00:04:41.960
regardless of whatever connection you're
one, that's what's going to happen.

86
00:04:41.960 --> 00:04:45.260
Now, you might be wondering like,
why do we need to do something like that?.

87
00:04:45.260 --> 00:04:48.110
Well, couple of ways we can handle it,
right?

88
00:04:48.110 --> 00:04:51.660
Daniel, would you recommend
somebody working in your network?

89
00:04:51.660 --> 00:04:55.810
Right, you have the copy of whatever your
files are and what they do is say, look,

90
00:04:55.810 --> 00:04:57.050
I need to take this with me.

91
00:04:57.050 --> 00:04:58.810
They could copy it down to their desktop,
right?

92
00:04:58.810 --> 00:05:01.920
They could just copy it down,
they're fine, they're ready to go.

93
00:05:01.920 --> 00:05:04.300
But then when the come back,
all of a sudden they go,

94
00:05:04.300 --> 00:05:06.910
wait a minute, that document
that was up on the file share

95
00:05:06.910 --> 00:05:08.960
is no longer the same as
the document I've been working with,

96
00:05:08.960 --> 00:05:13.370
and now they've copied it up there and
all of a sudden they override changes, and

97
00:05:13.370 --> 00:05:16.110
Daniel, in a situation like that,
that could be critical, right?

98
00:05:16.110 --> 00:05:17.770
>> Yeah, that could be disastrous,

99
00:05:17.770 --> 00:05:21.710
because if you have more than
one person working on that file.

100
00:05:21.710 --> 00:05:24.848
Well, Ronnie copies that
file down to his computer,

101
00:05:24.848 --> 00:05:27.020
I copy that file down to my computer.

102
00:05:27.020 --> 00:05:31.223
We go our separate ways, we both make
changes, I come to into work before Ronnie

103
00:05:31.223 --> 00:05:34.000
does, I go man I'm going
to upload my changes here.

104
00:05:34.000 --> 00:05:36.952
And I put that in and
I replace that file that we both copied,

105
00:05:36.952 --> 00:05:38.380
well it's good to go right?

106
00:05:38.380 --> 00:05:41.680
All my changes are there,
everything should be fine.

107
00:05:41.680 --> 00:05:45.940
Then Ronnie comes into work,
he uploads his file, what does it do?

108
00:05:45.940 --> 00:05:48.340
It overwrites my file.

109
00:05:48.340 --> 00:05:51.210
All the changes that I
have made are now gone and

110
00:05:51.210 --> 00:05:53.920
only the changes that
Ronnie has made remain.

111
00:05:53.920 --> 00:05:56.760
And that's not a good thing,
right, it's not what we want.

112
00:05:56.760 --> 00:05:59.190
We're kind of being
counterproductive at that point.

113
00:05:59.190 --> 00:06:03.860
We're both making changes to
the same file in an offline status,

114
00:06:03.860 --> 00:06:05.180
then there comes the problem right?

115
00:06:05.180 --> 00:06:07.690
We can't get those files to synchronize.

116
00:06:07.690 --> 00:06:11.510
This is where this offline
file idea comes in handy

117
00:06:11.510 --> 00:06:15.330
that's built in to the actual
operating system that Microsoft has so

118
00:06:15.330 --> 00:06:19.840
graciously given us to,
to deal with here in, in our show.

119
00:06:19.840 --> 00:06:21.490
It is a wonderful thing,
I've got to be honest with you,

120
00:06:21.490 --> 00:06:23.950
it is definitely one
of their better ideas.

121
00:06:23.950 --> 00:06:29.730
To be able for us both to work on the same
file offline, different computers, not

122
00:06:29.730 --> 00:06:33.720
connected to the network, and then come
together and those files synchronized.

123
00:06:33.720 --> 00:06:37.300
All his changes get applied,
all my changes get applied and

124
00:06:37.300 --> 00:06:38.470
nothing gets overwritten.

125
00:06:38.470 --> 00:06:39.680
This is awesome.

126
00:06:39.680 --> 00:06:42.470
>> There definitely is and there
sometimes what ends up happening though.

127
00:06:42.470 --> 00:06:45.890
Is that if those changes are too
different, right, instead of actually

128
00:06:45.890 --> 00:06:48.820
trying to say which change applies last,
because that's the one that actually

129
00:06:48.820 --> 00:06:53.020
kills you, is saying well, why don't you
just go ahead and keep both copies, and

130
00:06:53.020 --> 00:06:56.150
in a real productive environment,
that's exactly what you would want to do.

131
00:06:56.150 --> 00:06:58.650
Until you can actually merge
those changes together.

132
00:06:58.650 --> 00:07:02.490
There are ways, there are different types
of policies out there that will allow you

133
00:07:02.490 --> 00:07:06.560
to only merge the changes into
whatever that base file is, but

134
00:07:06.560 --> 00:07:08.680
that's a little bit beyond what
we're talking about right here.

135
00:07:08.680 --> 00:07:10.295
But at least for the offline files,

136
00:07:10.295 --> 00:07:13.975
what we can do now is actually set up our
computer just like we are at work, and

137
00:07:13.975 --> 00:07:18.095
the nice thing is to whatever individual
is taking that laptop out on the road,

138
00:07:18.095 --> 00:07:20.385
it really doesn't actually
act any differently.

139
00:07:20.385 --> 00:07:23.045
They're not going to move
the location of anything,

140
00:07:23.045 --> 00:07:25.455
it actually looks like they're connected
in network even though they're not.

141
00:07:25.455 --> 00:07:27.935
Now the way that works
is that they hide it.

142
00:07:27.935 --> 00:07:30.790
So they actually take inside of
the Windows folder somewhere,

143
00:07:30.790 --> 00:07:35.650
they make a special cache copy, and
that redirects it to right there so

144
00:07:35.650 --> 00:07:39.130
when you're actually not connected, it
doesn't connect up to the network share.

145
00:07:39.130 --> 00:07:42.348
It connects you to that hidden location,
and that way all the time when you're

146
00:07:42.348 --> 00:07:45.178
actually working with that individual
file and you are changing it,

147
00:07:45.178 --> 00:07:48.583
it's perfectly fine you can do that, but
you're not really writing it up there.

148
00:07:48.583 --> 00:07:52.347
And so what ends up happening then is
next time you come in from the field,

149
00:07:52.347 --> 00:07:56.666
you plugged your laptop into the network,
then it begins to try to communicate with

150
00:07:56.666 --> 00:08:00.763
the original file, and then that's
when synchronization begins to happen.

151
00:08:00.763 --> 00:08:05.045
And it really is up to whoever
the administrator is How those changes

152
00:08:05.045 --> 00:08:07.161
are going to be managed and kept.

153
00:08:07.161 --> 00:08:11.510
Whether, when you come back in, if there's
a disparity, or whether actually both

154
00:08:11.510 --> 00:08:15.306
copies are going to be saved until they
figure out how that merge is going to

155
00:08:15.306 --> 00:08:19.350
end up happening, all that is really
up to the network administrator.

156
00:08:19.350 --> 00:08:23.098
But at the beginning here, let me show
you what the result should normally be.

157
00:08:23.098 --> 00:08:27.060
So here it is, I got my Windows machine
that is now joined to the domain.

158
00:08:27.060 --> 00:08:31.550
And so, if I take a look then,
at what I'm connected to.

159
00:08:31.550 --> 00:08:34.960
I just went ahead and launched up
the Windows, or the File Explorer here.

160
00:08:34.960 --> 00:08:38.970
And in the File Explorer, if I select this
PC, I can see I already have a shared

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes take a look at using Powercfg from the command line.  The guys show that the same configuration settings cn be managed from the GUI in control panel.  Wes then shows how to see the current power plan on his machines using the CLI.  This interface shows us the main piece of information that we will use which is the GUID, Global Unique Identifier, that every power plan has to identify it.  Using some different options, Wes continues to demonstrate how to set a particular power plan as being active as well.  Lastly, the guys show us how to bring up html reports on energy efficiency and battery life that is good to see when dealing with power consumption issues in the workplace.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes show the management of BitLocker from the CLI.  Using the manage-bde command, they show how to enable bit locker when on both TPM based and non TPM based machines.  They also demonstrate how to verify the status.  Wes also takes us through the command to disable protectors and enable additional protectors too to make sure we get the combination of protections that we desire to have when using BitLocker for drive encryption.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes take a look using the command prompt to help support users on the network.  Many of the devices will be connecting to our network and cause Windows 10 categorize it as a connection profile.  They show the profiles can be changed through the command prompt by using powershell cmdlets.  You can also see the profiles through the netsh commands to show settings according to Wes.   Wes also demonstrates the use of the modern networking interface in Windows 10.  He does this to emphasize the new changes as well as to help the support technician to become more familiar with this newer interface.

go to Control Panel.

732
00:36:46.860 --> 00:36:51.070
And then Network and
Internet > Network and Sharing Center.

733
00:36:51.070 --> 00:36:54.470
Now notice it changed it to private for
us right away.

734
00:36:54.470 --> 00:36:55.830
So you can use that instead.

735
00:36:55.830 --> 00:36:57.220
Now, there's other ways you can get to it.

736
00:36:57.220 --> 00:36:57.951
You can go in and

737
00:36:57.951 --> 00:37:01.840
change, inside of the Advanced Windows
Firewall with Advanced Settings.

738
00:37:01.840 --> 00:37:04.450
You can go into your group policy and
change your network locations and

739
00:37:04.450 --> 00:37:06.930
stuff, and give you that access to do it.

740
00:37:06.930 --> 00:37:10.430
But this is actually a trouble
shooting recommended methodology

741
00:37:10.430 --> 00:37:12.430
from Microsoft that allows you do this.

742
00:37:12.430 --> 00:37:16.186
>> It's really just a quick and dirty
way to get that side bar to slide out.

743
00:37:16.186 --> 00:37:16.869
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

744
00:37:16.869 --> 00:37:20.540
give you a chance to pick the right one
if you picked the wrong one last time.

745
00:37:20.540 --> 00:37:22.350
Even if you're not looking
to join a home group.

746
00:37:22.350 --> 00:37:24.285
It just happens to be where
they've hidden that link.

747
00:37:24.285 --> 00:37:25.800
>> [LAUGH]
>> You can get that thing to come out and

748
00:37:25.800 --> 00:37:28.740
you can say, okay, this time I'm gonna
pick Yes, and now you're good to go.

749
00:37:28.740 --> 00:37:29.570
So, pretty cool little trick, Ronnie.

750
00:37:29.570 --> 00:37:30.806
>> It is a great little trick and

751
00:37:30.806 --> 00:37:33.847
it's something that we definitely
wanna make sure that we hang onto,

752
00:37:33.847 --> 00:37:36.780
because you're gonna see that
more than once, I guarantee.

753
00:37:36.780 --> 00:37:39.648
As users bring their laptops back in like,
yeah, I don't know why it's actually still

754
00:37:39.648 --> 00:37:41.525
connecting to public and
I'm still here on the network.

755
00:37:41.525 --> 00:37:42.071
>> Yep.

756
00:37:42.071 --> 00:37:44.596
>> Yep, you might wanna make
sure that you know that one.

757
00:37:44.596 --> 00:37:46.742
>> All right, well Ronnie, I know we
went a little long-winded on that one.

758
00:37:46.742 --> 00:37:48.519
But that was a lot of great information,
and

759
00:37:48.519 --> 00:37:51.315
information you're gonna need to
know to be successful on the exam.

760
00:37:51.315 --> 00:37:54.762
So make sure you paid attention,
go back and watch it a couple of times.

761
00:37:54.762 --> 00:37:58.199
But for now we're out of time, so
signing off, I'm Mike Rodrick.

762
00:37:58.199 --> 00:37:59.163
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

763
00:37:59.163 --> 00:38:00.591
>> And we'll see you next time.

764

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel describe some of the network security options provided in the Windows 10 operating system. They cover firewall basics and then go into detail on how to configure the Windows Firewall basic and advanced settings.
episodes.title: Configure Network Security
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:09.134
[MUSIC} All

2
00:00:09.134 --> 00:00:12.940
right.

3
00:00:12.940 --> 00:00:16.540
Greetings everyone and welcome to
another great episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:16.540 --> 00:00:19.740
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie,
here with me today is Mr. Mike Rodrick.

5
00:00:19.740 --> 00:00:20.830
How's it going today Mikey?

6
00:00:20.830 --> 00:00:24.330
>> It's going great Daniel, I'm excited to
be here because today we're going to be

7
00:00:24.330 --> 00:00:28.810
diving into the world of Windows 10 and
in particular, network security.

8
00:00:28.810 --> 00:00:30.270
Always a good time with network security,
right?

9
00:00:30.270 --> 00:00:33.780
>> Oh yeah, we love the network
security around here at ITProTV.

10
00:00:33.780 --> 00:00:37.820
We like to keep our viewers safe
while they're out there in the wild.

11
00:00:37.820 --> 00:00:41.900
Today specifically I think we're
going to go over Windows firewall.

12
00:00:41.900 --> 00:00:42.690
Firewalling is in.

13
00:00:42.690 --> 00:00:45.530
We're gonna introduce those topics and
make sure you understand them and

14
00:00:45.530 --> 00:00:48.910
then show how Windows
handles that situation.

15
00:00:48.910 --> 00:00:52.210
What we can do to prevent network attacks,
how we can keep bad guys out of our

16
00:00:52.210 --> 00:00:56.045
system, but still allow the actual
traffic that we want to allow

17
00:00:56.045 --> 00:00:59.165
using the firewall that's built into
the actual operating system itself.

18
00:00:59.165 --> 00:01:03.535
Now Mike, I know that you are well
adept at using the Windows firewall, so

19
00:01:03.535 --> 00:01:07.650
I'm going to learn at the feet of
the master here and watch you work.

20
00:01:07.650 --> 00:01:08.540
Where should we begin?

21
00:01:08.540 --> 00:01:10.930
>> I don't know about all that, but
we're going to talk about first,

22
00:01:10.930 --> 00:01:14.690
just what a firewall is, because we need
to make sure we've got that concept down.

23
00:01:14.690 --> 00:01:17.480
And I'm sure most of you at this point
in your career, if you're studying for

24
00:01:17.480 --> 00:01:22.080
this exam, you've already been through A+,
and Net+, and possibly even Security+.

25
00:01:22.080 --> 00:01:23.620
You've got an idea of what a firewall is,
but

26
00:01:23.620 --> 00:01:25.860
let's make sure we're
all on the same page.

27
00:01:25.860 --> 00:01:31.800
A firewall is just a way that we can put
up a barrier between a trusted network,

28
00:01:31.800 --> 00:01:35.310
and in this case we're going to be
looking at the operating system level,

29
00:01:35.310 --> 00:01:40.110
so a barrier between my PC and
the rest of the network.

30
00:01:40.110 --> 00:01:45.050
And that firewall allows me to control
what types of traffic are allowed to come

31
00:01:45.050 --> 00:01:49.440
into my PC as well as what types
of traffic allowed to leave my PC.

32
00:01:49.440 --> 00:01:54.910
Because as you guys know,
as we talk about a TCP/IP based network,

33
00:01:54.910 --> 00:01:57.380
when we establish a socket basically,

34
00:01:57.380 --> 00:02:01.550
or connection with another computer on
a TCP/IP network, we need three things.

35
00:02:01.550 --> 00:02:05.040
We need a protocol, we need an IP address,
and we need a port number.

36
00:02:06.440 --> 00:02:10.130
You typically, TCP, for your protocol,
your IP address of course is the IP

37
00:02:10.130 --> 00:02:13.920
address of your machine or the destination
that you're trying to connect to and

38
00:02:13.920 --> 00:02:19.690
then that port number tells it what type
of traffic this is, for the most part.

39
00:02:19.690 --> 00:02:23.350
And so we can use those port numbers
to control the types of traffic that

40
00:02:23.350 --> 00:02:24.250
are allowed to come in or out.

41
00:02:24.250 --> 00:02:28.265
So for example,
what if I'm running a web server,

42
00:02:28.265 --> 00:02:33.165
then I need to allow port 80
because that's my HTTP port, right?

43
00:02:33.165 --> 00:02:35.165
That's what that protocol travels over.

44
00:02:35.165 --> 00:02:38.075
I have to open up that
hole in the firewall.

45
00:02:38.075 --> 00:02:40.780
If I don't,
I can run my web server all day long,

46
00:02:40.780 --> 00:02:43.060
but nobody's gonna get to my webpage.

47
00:02:43.060 --> 00:02:46.180
>> Yeah, it's gonna have a little hard
time cuz that's what the firewall does.

48
00:02:46.180 --> 00:02:49.590
It says, hey you know what,
I'm just gonna block everything.

49
00:02:49.590 --> 00:02:52.110
This is a little something that
we like to call an implicit deny.

50
00:02:52.110 --> 00:02:55.890
That it just says, no matter what comes
through here I'm just gonna deny it.

51
00:02:55.890 --> 00:02:57.620
I'm just gonna drop that
traffic on the floor and

52
00:02:57.620 --> 00:03:02.080
say, it's not going through, it's my job
I'm the superhero of the network here.

53
00:03:02.080 --> 00:03:06.450
So we have to say hey now, there
are some exceptions we'd like to make.

54
00:03:06.450 --> 00:03:09.120
And we do that using ACLs right?

55
00:03:09.120 --> 00:03:09.680
>> Exactly.

56
00:03:09.680 --> 00:03:13.020
And that's a really great system that
they've got set up there with that

57
00:03:13.020 --> 00:03:18.020
implicit deny that Daniel mentioned
because know it doesn't start out wide

58
00:03:18.020 --> 00:03:21.140
open, and I have to really figure out
what it is I need to block, instead,

59
00:03:21.140 --> 00:03:24.860
we're going to block everything and
just allow what I want to allow.

60
00:03:24.860 --> 00:03:27.940
When you're first setting up a machine
sometimes that can be a troublesome,

61
00:03:27.940 --> 00:03:30.980
because something won't work, and you
realize, oh I've got to open up a hole in

62
00:03:30.980 --> 00:03:33.060
the firewall, and
then something else doesn't work,

63
00:03:33.060 --> 00:03:35.220
and oh I've got to open up
a hole in the firewall.

64
00:03:35.220 --> 00:03:39.200
But honestly a lot of applications
will actually help you through that,

65
00:03:39.200 --> 00:03:42.160
they'll say, hey do you want e to
make an exception for this, and

66
00:03:42.160 --> 00:03:45.420
really creating exceptions in
the firewall is not that difficult.

67
00:03:45.420 --> 00:03:49.750
So it's a lot easier, I think,
to start out with everything closed and

68
00:03:49.750 --> 00:03:51.120
only allow what you want to allow.

69
00:03:51.120 --> 00:03:54.980
So that implicit deny that
Dan's referring to and

70
00:03:54.980 --> 00:03:57.210
that's the way these firewalls work.

71
00:03:57.210 --> 00:03:58.400
Now firewalls are not new.

72
00:03:58.400 --> 00:04:02.761
They've been around all the way back
to Windows X HP Service Pack 3.

73
00:04:02.761 --> 00:04:08.570
That's where we first got a firewall
built into the client operating system.

74
00:04:08.570 --> 00:04:11.070
Prior to that,
we would have to download something.

75
00:04:11.070 --> 00:04:14.280
I remember, Daniel,
using things like ZoneAlarm Pro and

76
00:04:14.280 --> 00:04:16.930
a couple of others and
some free software like that.

77
00:04:16.930 --> 00:04:18.015
>> I used BlackIce.

78
00:04:18.015 --> 00:04:20.330
>> BlackIce was a very popular one.

79
00:04:20.330 --> 00:04:23.680
So those were the kind of things we would
download and we would put on our machine.

80
00:04:23.680 --> 00:04:27.680
Then when Service Pack 3 came out, all of
a sudden you've got this Windows firewall.

81
00:04:27.680 --> 00:04:30.170
For a long time there,
people got really confused,

82
00:04:30.170 --> 00:04:33.570
because then they'd be running two
firewalls and they wouldn't realize it.

83
00:04:33.570 --> 00:04:36.520
They had one that they had downloaded,
maybe paid for, and

84
00:04:36.520 --> 00:04:39.120
XP had that one built into it.

85
00:04:39.120 --> 00:04:40.460
You can run two firewalls.

86
00:04:40.460 --> 00:04:42.750
There's nothing that says you cannot.

87
00:04:42.750 --> 00:04:45.990
But if you think about that you've got
two walls that are blocking everything.

88
00:04:45.990 --> 00:04:49.840
I can open up a hole in one, that doesn't
open up the hole in the other one, so

89
00:04:49.840 --> 00:04:53.460
now I've got to remember to open up
that hole and the second one as well.

90
00:04:53.460 --> 00:04:54.540
It's really overkill,

91
00:04:54.540 --> 00:04:58.930
there's no real reason to run
two firewalls on the same PC.

92
00:04:58.930 --> 00:05:00.930
Now in a corporate environment,

93
00:05:00.930 --> 00:05:04.130
you're gonna have firewalls that
sit at the border of your network.

94
00:05:04.130 --> 00:05:07.720
And those control the traffic that's
even allowed to come into your network.

95
00:05:07.720 --> 00:05:12.150
And then once that traffic gets o the
network the firewall at your host machine

96
00:05:12.150 --> 00:05:16.360
gets a chance to filter it as well so
you kind of are running two there but, but

97
00:05:16.360 --> 00:05:17.140
not on the same machine.

98
00:05:18.790 --> 00:05:21.770
So a firewall and if we just look at my
screen here just a quick refresher again.

99
00:05:21.770 --> 00:05:26.190
You know a firewall is basically
sit in between you and

100
00:05:26.190 --> 00:05:28.910
an un-trusted portion of
the network typically.

101
00:05:28.910 --> 00:05:32.710
A lot of times that's in
the case of that network firewall

102
00:05:32.710 --> 00:05:34.110
that's usually the internet.

103
00:05:34.110 --> 00:05:38.630
In a corporate environment though, this
firewall is running on my local machine.

104
00:05:38.630 --> 00:05:41.850
And it's protecting me from traffic
on my corporate network, and

105
00:05:41.850 --> 00:05:43.820
you might think to yourself, well, why?

106
00:05:43.820 --> 00:05:45.030
It's your corporate network.

107
00:05:45.030 --> 00:05:47.580
Don't you trust your corporate network?

108
00:05:47.580 --> 00:05:49.940
To a certain degree, I do, right?

109
00:05:49.940 --> 00:05:53.030
But what if one machine gets
compromised on my network?

110
00:05:53.030 --> 00:05:57.780
Bad guy somehow makes it through that
corporate firewall, my network firewall,

111
00:05:57.780 --> 00:06:00.510
and compromises a machine on my network.

112
00:06:00.510 --> 00:06:02.330
Now that bad guy's on the inside.

113
00:06:02.330 --> 00:06:05.580
And if I don't have any firewalls
on the individual machines,

114
00:06:05.580 --> 00:06:07.550
that bad guy's got free
reign on the network, right?

115
00:06:07.550 --> 00:06:10.330
I lose that one layer of security, and

116
00:06:10.330 --> 00:06:12.540
it's all about layers when
it comes to security.

117
00:06:12.540 --> 00:06:13.950
I want one layer after another,

118
00:06:13.950 --> 00:06:17.285
after another that they have to try
to break through because the more

119
00:06:17.285 --> 00:06:22.015
layers they have to go through, the better
chance I have of detecting that attack.

120
00:06:22.015 --> 00:06:25.925
Either thwarting the attack altogether,
because they're really good at one task,

121
00:06:25.925 --> 00:06:29.470
but they're not so good about getting
through host based firewalls.

122
00:06:29.470 --> 00:06:32.580
Or maybe they can get through that,
but it sets off an alarm.

123
00:06:32.580 --> 00:06:34.850
I notice that something's
going on with my firewall.

124
00:06:34.850 --> 00:06:36.240
So layer after layer.

125
00:06:36.240 --> 00:06:40.370
That's why just because you're running
a network based firewall to protect your

126
00:06:40.370 --> 00:06:45.170
corporate network, you still wanna
run firewalls on the individual host.

127
00:06:45.170 --> 00:06:47.250
And you can see,
as Daniel's drawn up here very nicely,

128
00:06:47.250 --> 00:06:50.560
like the green traffic is
being allowed through.

129
00:06:50.560 --> 00:06:53.530
So my firewall has basically
an access control list.

130
00:06:53.530 --> 00:06:57.460
It controls what type of traffic is
allowed to come through and what cannot.

131
00:06:57.460 --> 00:07:01.451
The red traffic, I like your little
iris there, that's very nice.

132
00:07:01.451 --> 00:07:03.500
>> [LAUGH]
>> Is going to be blocked at the firewall.

133
00:07:03.500 --> 00:07:06.540
So we've chosen to block
whatever type of traffic that is.

134
00:07:06.540 --> 00:07:10.320
Now it would be nice if we could make
a firewall rule that said, block viruses,

135
00:07:10.320 --> 00:07:12.050
but you can't do that.

136
00:07:12.050 --> 00:07:15.300
Firewall rules are all
based on port numbers,

137
00:07:15.300 --> 00:07:19.270
which is why we made you memorize all
those port numbers back in Network+.

138
00:07:19.270 --> 00:07:21.550
Because If you're going to
create a firewall rule,

139
00:07:21.550 --> 00:07:26.170
if your boss comes to you and says I need
you to set up a firewall rule that is

140
00:07:26.170 --> 00:07:31.890
going to allow FTP traffic or
is going to block ICMP, or what have you.

141
00:07:31.890 --> 00:07:34.880
When you go to create that rule,
you need to know what port number that is.

142
00:07:34.880 --> 00:07:36.920
Otherwise you're gonna have
a hard time creating that rule.

143
00:07:36.920 --> 00:07:39.400
Now there are some wizards
in there that can let you

144
00:07:39.400 --> 00:07:44.240
pick some protocols from a drop down,
but you still really should be familiar

145
00:07:44.240 --> 00:07:47.180
with those port numbers that are assigned
to those different protocols.

146
00:07:48.540 --> 00:07:52.944
All right, so now that we've got a basic
understanding of what a firewall is,

147
00:07:52.944 --> 00:07:56.634
where it sits, again,
it came out back in XP service back three.

148
00:07:56.634 --> 00:07:59.920
Daniel, I tell you, I like the firewall
that's built into Windows.

149
00:07:59.920 --> 00:08:00.869
It does a good job.

150
00:08:00.869 --> 00:08:02.480
It's easy to configure.

151
00:08:02.480 --> 00:08:03.540
I don't know, do you turn it off and

152
00:08:03.540 --> 00:08:06.350
then go back to a software,
another one that you've bought?

153
00:08:06.350 --> 00:08:07.550
Or do you just use the one built in?

154
00:08:07.550 --> 00:08:09.540
>> Yeah I tend to stick with
the one that's built in.

155
00:08:09.540 --> 00:08:11.360
It does a fine job of it.

156
00:08:11.360 --> 00:08:14.925
Especially when you get into the more
advanced areas of the Windows firewall,

157
00:08:14.925 --> 00:08:17.032
it will do just everything
you need it to do, so

158
00:08:17.032 --> 00:08:20.830
I haven't really needed to go to any kind
of third party solution for firewalling.

159
00:08:20.830 --> 00:08:24.630
But I was in that corporate network again,
you're gonna have hardware firewalls, and

160
00:08:24.630 --> 00:08:26.720
you're gonna have software firewalls.

161
00:08:26.720 --> 00:08:27.910
When you have a larger network,

162
00:08:27.910 --> 00:08:32.410
you probably are going to have those
hardware firewalls that they're dedicated

163
00:08:32.410 --> 00:08:35.340
to firewalling traffic that's going in and
out of your network.

164
00:08:35.340 --> 00:08:39.380
And that's so that your computers don't
have to handle that workload, let that

165
00:08:39.380 --> 00:08:43.330
piece of hardware be dedicated to that
task, and then if it makes it past like

166
00:08:43.330 --> 00:08:47.680
Mike was saying, once we have that layered
security, those defenses are still up.

167
00:08:47.680 --> 00:08:48.938
And we still have another defense, but

168
00:08:48.938 --> 00:08:51.180
it's not doing a ton of
that in the backgrounds.

169
00:08:51.180 --> 00:08:56.190
But for just home uses and small home
office, those little firewalls built

170
00:08:56.190 --> 00:08:58.660
into the Windows Operating System,
they do a fine job.

171
00:08:58.660 --> 00:09:03.240
>> All right, so what I'm gonna do,
let's take a look at some things we can

172
00:09:03.240 --> 00:09:06.960
do to look at our firewall settings,
see how we can go about configuring that.

173
00:09:06.960 --> 00:09:10.860
First thing I wanna do is,
let's just look at it.

174
00:09:10.860 --> 00:09:16.154
So over here on my client, I'm going
to do a quick search for firewall.

175
00:09:16.154 --> 00:09:19.181
And I know there's 100 different
ways to get everywhere on Windows,

176
00:09:19.181 --> 00:09:21.076
I find that search bar
just to be the easiest.

177
00:09:21.076 --> 00:09:25.020
You should familiarize yourself with the
control panel, with the way you navigate

178
00:09:25.020 --> 00:09:29.131
around in Windows 10, because on the exam,
they might have you going one way instead

179
00:09:29.131 --> 00:09:32.140
of another, so make sure you
familiarize yourself with that.

180
00:09:32.140 --> 00:09:35.595
But I'm just going to click
on Windows firewall, and

181
00:09:35.595 --> 00:09:37.885
that's gonna open up my basic firewall.

182
00:09:37.885 --> 00:09:40.835
Now here's something that gets
a little bit confusing if

183
00:09:40.835 --> 00:09:43.295
you're first playing with
the firewall at Windows.

184
00:09:43.295 --> 00:09:45.555
You actually have two
different firewall consoles.

185
00:09:45.555 --> 00:09:48.367
You might have noticed when I searched for
firewall,

186
00:09:48.367 --> 00:09:51.930
all right, I have a couple of options.

00:21:34.364 --> 00:21:37.262
Now let's take a peek,
and what I'm gonna do,

411
00:21:37.262 --> 00:21:41.841
I'm gonna flip over to this server and
I'm gonna open up a command prompt.

412
00:21:44.441 --> 00:21:51.358
And I'm gonna try to ping that client
machine, if I can remember its name.

00:21:51.358 --> 00:21:53.818
And, it's going to reply just fine.

414
00:21:53.818 --> 00:21:56.036
So, I'm going to flip back over here and
take a look.

00:21:56.036 --> 00:22:02.255
And, if we look at my firewall rules,
right here, I can see a couple of rules.

416
00:22:02.255 --> 00:22:04.376
Let me make that just a hair wider.

00:22:04.376 --> 00:22:10.317
So, I've got File and

00:22:10.317 --> 00:22:12.157
Notice this one says, Private.

00:22:12.157 --> 00:22:16.382
There's also one for domain, and
it's set to Yes, and the one for

00:22:16.382 --> 00:22:18.410
public is set to No.

00:22:18.410 --> 00:22:20.738
What if I come over here and
turn this guy off?

422
00:22:20.738 --> 00:22:23.760
I'm just gonna right-click on it and
choose Disable Rule.

423
00:22:24.910 --> 00:22:32.196
And now, if I go back over to that server
and try to ping again, notice it failed.

424
00:22:32.196 --> 00:22:36.990
It's able to resolve the name into an IP
address, but the request times out.

425
00:22:36.990 --> 00:22:40.296
See if we can quit that here.

426
00:22:40.296 --> 00:22:41.491
I could do that same thing.

427
00:22:45.369 --> 00:22:47.480
Just let that thing run for a little bit.

428
00:22:48.490 --> 00:22:51.734
So you see, we're getting, request timed
out, request timed out, request timed out.

429
00:22:51.734 --> 00:22:55.817
If I flip back over here and
turn that back on for

430
00:22:55.817 --> 00:22:59.700
the domain profile, see how long it takes.

431
00:23:00.870 --> 00:23:02.756
And there it goes, all of the sudden,
I'm getting replies.

432
00:23:02.756 --> 00:23:06.085
So, as soon as I open that hole
up in the firewall, it says, oh,

433
00:23:06.085 --> 00:23:09.322
I can now allow ICMP traffic
because I'm on a domain network.

434
00:23:09.322 --> 00:23:14.152
So the domain profile's being applied, and
now, there's an exception to allow that.

435
00:23:14.152 --> 00:23:16.387
And I'm gonna go ahead and
allow that to come through.

436
00:23:16.387 --> 00:23:18.186
So, that's how that firewall works.

437
00:23:18.186 --> 00:23:21.527
We just go in there, and we make
the appropriate exceptions in here.

438
00:23:21.527 --> 00:23:25.289
Now, the last thing I wanna show you
about with this Windows firewall advanced

439
00:23:25.289 --> 00:23:27.294
security is how you create a custom rule.

440
00:23:27.294 --> 00:23:31.004
We've got all these pre-built rules
that are pretty easy to work with.

441
00:23:31.004 --> 00:23:33.874
If I double-click on one
of these pre-built rules,

442
00:23:33.874 --> 00:23:35.994
you can see you can always modify them.

443
00:23:35.994 --> 00:23:37.236
You're not stuck with them.

444
00:23:37.236 --> 00:23:39.242
If I want to allow it,
allow it if it's secure.

445
00:23:39.242 --> 00:23:41.232
We're gonna talk about that later.

446
00:23:41.232 --> 00:23:46.413
Meanwhile, I wanna show you
here is the Advance tab,

447
00:23:46.413 --> 00:23:50.684
specify profiles where this rule applies.

448
00:23:50.684 --> 00:23:52.471
Notice Domain is selected, so

449
00:23:52.471 --> 00:23:56.870
that is how I can change that on
one of those pre-existing rules.

450
00:23:56.870 --> 00:23:58.640
I wanna make a new rule.

451
00:23:58.640 --> 00:24:01.634
Simply gonna right-click over here and
choose New Rule.

452
00:24:04.096 --> 00:24:06.850
And then I'd get my handy dandy wizard.

453
00:24:06.850 --> 00:24:07.536
Now I've got a few options.

454
00:24:07.536 --> 00:24:12.400
I've got Program, which is gonna allow
me to browse and find an executable.

455
00:24:12.400 --> 00:24:15.608
I've downloaded something,
I wanted to, it needs Internet access,

456
00:24:15.608 --> 00:24:18.343
it's got return traffic,
maybe for updates or something.

457
00:24:18.343 --> 00:24:21.100
I can allow that program through.

458
00:24:21.100 --> 00:24:23.890
I can also do a port number rule,

459
00:24:23.890 --> 00:24:27.300
which would be based on
the port number of the traffic.

460
00:24:27.300 --> 00:24:30.810
I can do Predefined, and you can see
a whole bunch are prebuilt in here.

461
00:24:30.810 --> 00:24:33.710
These are very handy when you're
setting up things like branch cash.

462
00:24:33.710 --> 00:24:35.530
Cuz there's a lot of different
ports you need to open up.

463
00:24:35.530 --> 00:24:37.692
So they've got some nice pre-built rules.

464
00:24:37.692 --> 00:24:40.443
A lot of this, though,
might be handled through group policy, so

465
00:24:40.443 --> 00:24:42.472
we might not be doing it
on the client end itself.

466
00:24:42.472 --> 00:24:45.630
Now I do wanna talk about the difference
between program and port.

467
00:24:45.630 --> 00:24:49.959
Cuz let's say you download a program, and
it tells you in the instructions that

468
00:24:49.959 --> 00:24:54.105
you're gonna have to open up port 4000,
we will just make one up right.

469
00:24:54.105 --> 00:24:56.490
Well, what do I choose?

470
00:24:56.490 --> 00:24:58.360
Do I go to do program and say, alright,

471
00:24:58.360 --> 00:25:00.410
this program is allowed
to go to the firewall?

472
00:25:00.410 --> 00:25:02.280
Or do I go to Port and open up port 4000?

473
00:25:02.280 --> 00:25:04.056
What's the difference, right?

474
00:25:04.056 --> 00:25:05.751
Cuz you think well it might be the same.

475
00:25:05.751 --> 00:25:08.395
There's actually a pretty
big difference there.

476
00:25:08.395 --> 00:25:12.335
If you do a program,
if it changes port numbers,

477
00:25:12.335 --> 00:25:13.435
that program would still be allowed.

478
00:25:13.435 --> 00:25:14.334
It is looking at the executables.

479
00:25:14.334 --> 00:25:17.724
It says, all right, any time this runs,
I am gonna allow that traffic.

480
00:25:17.724 --> 00:25:20.025
If it has returned traffic,
I am gonna allow it.

481
00:25:20.025 --> 00:25:22.985
So if that program changes port numbers.

482
00:25:22.985 --> 00:25:25.929
Or some programs might have
a main port number, but

483
00:25:25.929 --> 00:25:30.585
then to double up on their bandwidth or to
speed things up, they might open up some

484
00:25:30.585 --> 00:25:35.540
of those high range dynamic ports to get
that traffic to come in faster, right?

485
00:25:35.540 --> 00:25:38.140
Well if I do it by a program,
that's not gonna be a problem

486
00:25:38.140 --> 00:25:41.890
because it says all right anything this
program opens up I'm gonna allow through.

487
00:25:43.170 --> 00:25:46.610
So you better trust that application
if you're gonna do it that way.

488
00:25:46.610 --> 00:25:50.000
If you do it by port number,
it's that specific port.

489
00:25:50.000 --> 00:25:53.399
So if that program needs other ports,
it won't be able to open them up.

490
00:25:53.399 --> 00:25:55.930
You're gonna have to open
those ports up yourself.

491
00:25:55.930 --> 00:26:00.131
Also if some other program uses
that same port, it'll be allowed,

492
00:26:00.131 --> 00:26:03.120
even though you might
not have wanted it to.

493
00:26:03.120 --> 00:26:06.210
So when you do a port number,
you are saying, hey, port 4000 is open,

494
00:26:06.210 --> 00:26:07.841
I don't care who's going through it.

495
00:26:07.841 --> 00:26:10.830
That could be a considered
a security risk.

496
00:26:10.830 --> 00:26:13.620
Something else could take advantage
of the fact that that port's open.

497
00:26:13.620 --> 00:26:16.300
If you do it by program, the port's
open when that program needs it.

498
00:26:16.300 --> 00:26:19.517
And when that program doesn't need
it anymore, that port's closed.

499
00:26:19.517 --> 00:26:20.537
Nothing else is gonna be able to use it.

500
00:26:20.537 --> 00:26:24.840
So you actually get a little more security
out of doing the program way, as well as

501
00:26:24.840 --> 00:26:29.640
the ability to handle those dynamic port
generations that the program might need.

502
00:26:29.640 --> 00:26:32.685
>> I guess that begs the question,
Mike, why would we ever use ports?

503
00:26:32.685 --> 00:26:35.680
[LAUGH]
>> Only if it's something

504
00:26:35.680 --> 00:26:38.180
that needs to be open for
different programs and

505
00:26:38.180 --> 00:26:40.890
you don't want to list them all out
there do you do the port number.

506
00:26:40.890 --> 00:26:42.367
Like port 80, for web traffic.

507
00:26:42.367 --> 00:26:45.260
Or 3389 remote desktop.

508
00:26:45.260 --> 00:26:47.802
Cuz that's remote desktop,
remote assistance, and things like that.

509
00:26:47.802 --> 00:26:50.692
So it might be easier sometimes
to do that port another way.

510
00:26:50.692 --> 00:26:52.230
>> Gotcha, so kind of the reverse.

511
00:26:52.230 --> 00:26:55.770
If you have one port that a bunch of
programs are using, you open the port.

512
00:26:55.770 --> 00:26:59.529
If you have a bunch of programs,
yeah, you get what I'm saying.

513
00:26:59.529 --> 00:27:00.183
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, exactly.

514
00:27:00.183 --> 00:27:01.564
Exactly.
>> You get where I'm going with this.

515
00:27:01.564 --> 00:27:03.894
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] All right, and

516
00:27:03.894 --> 00:27:05.990
then the last one is just Custom.

517
00:27:05.990 --> 00:27:09.860
This one will let you walk through
all of the different options.

518
00:27:09.860 --> 00:27:12.493
So if I go, I'm gonna go ahead and
click next here,

519
00:27:12.493 --> 00:27:16.710
cuz I get to see all the options not
program specific, not port specific.

520
00:27:16.710 --> 00:27:19.366
And you can see all programs or
a specific program.

521
00:27:19.366 --> 00:27:21.290
I'll leave it on all programs.

522
00:27:21.290 --> 00:27:24.784
And then for my protocol,
I get my drop-down list.

523
00:27:24.784 --> 00:27:29.367
And I'm just going to repeat that ping
firewall rule just to make something here.

524
00:27:29.367 --> 00:27:33.629
So, I go to ICMPv4, and
you can customize this.

525
00:27:33.629 --> 00:27:38.093
Like, if you want to do all ICMP types,
or just echo requests,

526
00:27:38.093 --> 00:27:42.244
not like time sync or
things like that, we can click okay.

527
00:27:42.244 --> 00:27:43.869
I'll click Next.

528
00:27:43.869 --> 00:27:47.851
And then I can specify to or
from IP addresses.

529
00:27:47.851 --> 00:27:49.330
So I could limit this.

530
00:27:49.330 --> 00:27:53.009
I could say I wanna allow ping, but
only if it's coming from my subnet.

531
00:27:53.009 --> 00:27:55.280
Or from a particular machine.

532
00:27:55.280 --> 00:27:55.924
I'm gonna leave it wide open.

533
00:27:55.924 --> 00:27:58.090
I'll click Next.

534
00:27:58.090 --> 00:28:00.391
And then Allow, or Block,
or Allow if secure.

535
00:28:00.391 --> 00:28:03.201
We're gonna talk about
the Allow if secure later on.

536
00:28:03.201 --> 00:28:04.767
I'll click Next.

537
00:28:04.767 --> 00:28:07.785
And then what profile do
I wanna apply this to?

538
00:28:07.785 --> 00:28:10.898
I don't want Public, but
I do want Domain or Private.

539
00:28:10.898 --> 00:28:12.313
I'll click Next.

540
00:28:12.313 --> 00:28:17.061
I'll give it a name, ICMPv4 In.

541
00:28:17.061 --> 00:28:21.210
Then I'll click Finish.

542
00:28:21.210 --> 00:28:25.880
And now if I go back now,
weird little glitch, does this every time.

543
00:28:25.880 --> 00:28:29.356
When you create your rule, the firewall
console, the advanced firewall,

544
00:28:29.356 --> 00:28:31.927
didn't close,
it just hides behind everything else.

545
00:28:31.927 --> 00:28:33.205
I'm just gonna bring it back to the front.

546
00:28:33.205 --> 00:28:36.605
And if we scroll up to the top,
there's my new rule I created.

547
00:28:36.605 --> 00:28:38.172
I can see it's turned on.

548
00:28:38.172 --> 00:28:44.775
If I go back down here and
turn this one off, And this one off.

549
00:28:46.100 --> 00:28:48.574
But I've got this rule that's allowing it.

550
00:28:48.574 --> 00:28:50.176
Let's prove that my rule is working.

551
00:28:50.176 --> 00:28:51.534
I come back over here.

552
00:28:51.534 --> 00:28:52.684
I do that ping again.

553
00:28:52.684 --> 00:28:57.094
And everything's working just fine,
because of the rule I created it says

554
00:28:57.094 --> 00:28:59.688
allow this type of
traffic to come through.

555
00:28:59.688 --> 00:29:04.009
And that is really working with
the basic firewall settings,

556
00:29:04.009 --> 00:29:07.760
as well as that
Windows Firewall Advanced Security.

557
00:29:07.760 --> 00:29:09.442
We got a few more things we
need to talk about though,

558
00:29:09.442 --> 00:29:11.714
we need to talk about connection
security rules and things like that.

559
00:29:11.714 --> 00:29:12.890
>> Yeah, we do.

560
00:29:12.890 --> 00:29:17.000
But this was a great primer on the
firewall, especially the Windows firewall.

561
00:29:17.000 --> 00:29:19.170
That's something you're definitely
gonna need to know for that exam.

562
00:29:19.170 --> 00:29:20.483
They're gonna ask you a question or

00:29:20.483 --> 00:29:21.770
I guarantee it.

564
00:29:21.770 --> 00:29:23.512
Hopefully Mike has done a great job.

565
00:29:23.512 --> 00:29:26.338
It was fantastic demonstrations for
us today.

566
00:29:26.338 --> 00:29:27.855
We are gonna have to make a part two for
this show,

567
00:29:27.855 --> 00:29:29.409
cuz there's a little bit
more we need to discuss.

568
00:29:29.409 --> 00:29:31.162
Hopefully, we'll see you there.

569
00:29:31.162 --> 00:29:32.580
Thanks for watching.

570
00:29:32.580 --> 00:29:35.685
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lawry.

00:29:35.685 --> 00:29:36.869
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

00:29:36.869 --> 00:29:37.610

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.769 --> 00:00:16.740
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another fantastic episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.740 --> 00:00:17.920
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie.

4
00:00:17.920 --> 00:00:20.180
Here with me today yet
again, Mr. Mike Rodrick.

5
00:00:20.180 --> 00:00:21.010
How's it going Mike?

6
00:00:21.010 --> 00:00:22.010
>> Oh it's going great Daniel.

7
00:00:22.010 --> 00:00:26.000
I am excited as always to be here because
we're doing our network security and

8
00:00:26.000 --> 00:00:27.400
we're gonna take it up a notch here.

9
00:00:27.400 --> 00:00:30.670
We're moving to that next level
when it comes to network security.

10
00:00:30.670 --> 00:00:34.260
>> That's right, we're looking at
Windows 10, specifically because well,

11
00:00:34.260 --> 00:00:35.440
Windows 10 is out.

12
00:00:35.440 --> 00:00:37.462
I'm sure you guys are preparing for
the exam.

13
00:00:37.462 --> 00:00:41.000
You wanna get that certification in
the mail with your nice name on it.

14
00:00:41.000 --> 00:00:43.588
And when looking at
the Windows Security here, well,

15
00:00:43.588 --> 00:00:47.247
if you looked at our previous episode we
talked about the Windows Firewall and

16
00:00:47.247 --> 00:00:50.699
behold there are still some more
security settings for us to go through.

17
00:00:50.699 --> 00:00:52.645
So that's what we're gonna tackle today.

18
00:00:52.645 --> 00:00:54.500
Mike, where do we begin?

19
00:00:54.500 --> 00:00:56.290
>> Well,
with this one what we're gonna do,

20
00:00:56.290 --> 00:00:58.510
we did talk about that firewall but, and

21
00:00:58.510 --> 00:01:02.840
we saw the firewall with advanced security
and one thing I didn't say was, why?

22
00:01:02.840 --> 00:01:05.200
Why is it called
the Windows Firewall Advanced Security?

23
00:01:05.200 --> 00:01:08.750
I think I mentioned that it
had more granular control, but

24
00:01:08.750 --> 00:01:10.230
there's really more to it than that.

25
00:01:10.230 --> 00:01:11.830
Let's go ahead and open that guy up.

26
00:01:11.830 --> 00:01:14.719
I'm gonna search for
firewall again this time,

27
00:01:14.719 --> 00:01:19.384
I'm gonna launch the Windows Firewall
Advanced Security right off the Menu.

28
00:01:19.384 --> 00:01:23.257
And when we open this guy up,
we're gonna see that, as we saw before,

29
00:01:23.257 --> 00:01:26.670
I've got an inbound rules,
I've got an outbound rules, but

30
00:01:26.670 --> 00:01:29.280
I also have Connection Security Rules.

31
00:01:29.280 --> 00:01:31.940
And that was the big change,
that's why the new console.

32
00:01:31.940 --> 00:01:35.230
Because prior to this,
you had your Windows Firewall settings,

33
00:01:35.230 --> 00:01:39.250
that basic console that we've seen,
and we had our IPsec settings.

34
00:01:39.250 --> 00:01:43.650
This was a different console,
it was a snap-in that you had to create.

35
00:01:43.650 --> 00:01:46.430
And they were two separate tools, and

36
00:01:46.430 --> 00:01:51.680
this one combines them, because really
they need to be used together anyway.

37
00:01:51.680 --> 00:01:56.665
It makes sense that they kinda put it all
in this one console, giving easy access

38
00:01:56.665 --> 00:02:01.015
to both sets of configuration,
your firewall as well as your IPsec, and

39
00:02:01.015 --> 00:02:03.725
they just call it
Connection Security Rules.

40
00:02:03.725 --> 00:02:06.135
Now, let's talk about what that is there.

41
00:02:06.135 --> 00:02:10.405
We know at this point that a firewall
is what controls the traffic,

42
00:02:10.405 --> 00:02:15.640
allows it to come through or leave my
machine, I can block it if I need to.

43
00:02:15.640 --> 00:02:18.770
Connection Security Rules talk
about whether that traffic

44
00:02:18.770 --> 00:02:23.550
needs to be authenticated,
whether it needs to be encrypted or not.

45
00:02:23.550 --> 00:02:27.940
So we're gonna protect that traffic
as it's traveling across the network.

46
00:02:27.940 --> 00:02:29.460
But there still both need to be.

47
00:02:29.460 --> 00:02:34.610
In other words, if I open up a hole in the
firewall, that'll allow that particular

48
00:02:34.610 --> 00:02:39.160
type of traffic come through, but it won't
authenticate it and it won't encrypt it.

49
00:02:39.160 --> 00:02:43.580
I can take my IPsec rules, my connection
security rules, and I can say,

50
00:02:43.580 --> 00:02:48.800
anytime this type of traffic comes across,
I wanna authenticate it and or encrypt it.

51
00:02:48.800 --> 00:02:51.090
But that doesn't allow
it through the firewall.

52
00:02:51.090 --> 00:02:52.910
You could make that rule just fine.

53
00:02:52.910 --> 00:02:55.760
But if the firewall didn't
have an exception it's still

54
00:02:55.760 --> 00:02:57.280
slamming into that firewall.

55
00:02:57.280 --> 00:02:58.180
So you have to do both.

56
00:02:58.180 --> 00:03:02.360
You have to open up the hole in
the firewall as well as decide whether or

57
00:03:02.360 --> 00:03:06.404
not you want to encrypt, or authenticate,
or both that type of traffic.

58
00:03:06.404 --> 00:03:10.040
So it makes sense that they
put it in the same console.

59
00:03:10.040 --> 00:03:11.100
And let's see how it works.

60
00:03:11.100 --> 00:03:14.940
What I'm gonna do is I'm gonna
open up a command prompt here, and

61
00:03:14.940 --> 00:03:17.460
I'm going to ping my server.

62
00:03:17.460 --> 00:03:20.590
I've got a guy rtr01 out

00:25:56.740 --> 00:26:01.208
Like now I can double-click on
a machine and any shares it has I'm

write I can double-click on it and

00:26:11.520 --> 00:26:15.250
the UNC path to get to it,

00:26:15.250 --> 00:26:17.720
>> Yeah, I think Microsoft
has done a really good job of

00:26:17.720 --> 00:26:19.130
using words like discovery.

00:26:19.130 --> 00:26:19.790
Right?

00:26:19.790 --> 00:26:21.500

Here specifically we're

I go to that network area

So I've seen that plenty of times,

00:27:16.720 --> 00:27:19.020
I turned it on,
everything was working fine.

00:27:19.020 --> 00:27:21.850
You don't realize, oh,

So make sure you get that right as well.

553
00:27:23.408 --> 00:27:23.970
>> Yeah, and

that's a great point because sometimes

555
00:27:28.167 --> 00:27:31.673
So when you're doing that troubleshooting,
go check and see what profiles we implied.

556
00:27:31.673 --> 00:27:35.233
Right?
I showed you or you probably saw in there,

00:27:35.233 --> 00:27:40.510
when I had that domain profile

00:27:40.510 --> 00:27:43.010

If I go in there and I see public is

00:27:48.030 --> 00:27:51.618

562
00:27:51.618 --> 00:27:53.047
A lot of times disabling and

enabling a network adaptor can

Sometimes you have to dive in and

565
00:28:00.779 --> 00:28:03.590
So a couple things to think about

566
00:28:03.590 --> 00:28:04.402
>> That's right.

567

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel show you how to troubleshoot common issues related to access and authorization. Specifically mentioned here is working with NTFS and share permissions and learning how to utilize the Effective Access Permissions to see exactly what security is being applied. Also covered is securing access to removable media using group policy.
episodes.title: Supporting Data Security

1

[MUSIC]

2

And so,

15

>> Yes, the dreaded permissions.

16
00:00:43.090 --> 00:00:47.398
What do I do when someone calls up and
says, hey you know, I've been working in

17
00:00:47.398 --> 00:00:51.379
HR for a while, I'm starting to do
a little more over here in research and

00:00:51.379 --> 00:00:54.020

reasearch and developement, so I'm gonna

00:01:03.770 --> 00:01:07.880
I'm gonna have to go into NTFS and say,
hey there's some permissions in here.

23
00:01:07.880 --> 00:01:11.290
How is it that I need to set these things

24
00:01:11.290 --> 00:01:15.775
Maybe you got a new person, roles change,
new people come in, people leave out,

25
00:01:15.775 --> 00:01:19.830
you gotta revoke and add and
do all sorts of hunky, weird stuff.

26
00:01:19.830 --> 00:01:23.827
But it's all about making sure that
the right people have the right access and

27
00:01:23.827 --> 00:01:27.763
the wrong people don't have the access,
the access of release privilege,

28
00:01:27.763 --> 00:01:28.947
I think it's called?

29
00:01:28.947 --> 00:01:29.974
>> Principal of Least?

30
00:01:29.974 --> 00:01:31.470
>> Yes, Principle of Least Privilege,
that's it.

31
00:01:31.470 --> 00:01:32.900
That's what we're looking at today.

32
00:01:32.900 --> 00:01:36.470
How can we set these things up correctly
so that that actually applies?

33
00:01:36.470 --> 00:01:38.150
Mike, you're gonna help us
out with that today, right?

34
00:01:38.150 --> 00:01:39.200
>> I sure am gonna try.

35
00:01:39.200 --> 00:01:42.640
You know, when it comes to managing
permissions, as Daniel said,

36
00:01:42.640 --> 00:01:44.610
it can be a very complex thing.

37
00:01:44.610 --> 00:01:46.770
It takes a lot of planning and
it's something that gets,

38
00:01:46.770 --> 00:01:50.130
usually in an enterprise environment,
gets developed over time here.

39
00:01:50.130 --> 00:01:52.450
We've come up with a plan, a strategy, and

40
00:01:52.450 --> 00:01:55.640
we're gonna follow Microsoft's
best practices more than likely.

41
00:01:55.640 --> 00:01:59.300
And that means following
something known as a AGDLP,

42
00:01:59.300 --> 00:02:02.680
which is where we put our
accounts into our global groups,

43
00:02:02.680 --> 00:02:06.500
which go into domain local groups,
which are given access to the resource.

44
00:02:06.500 --> 00:02:10.040
For this exam,
I think we did talk about that,

45
00:02:10.040 --> 00:02:12.790
in some of our other episodes
where we went over permissions.

46
00:02:12.790 --> 00:02:16.260
Really, we covered that pretty
good in the server level classes.

47
00:02:16.260 --> 00:02:19.560
But it's all about assigning permissions,
and really, what I want to stress here is

48
00:02:19.560 --> 00:02:24.170
that we're typically assigning permissions
to groups, not to individual users.

49
00:02:24.170 --> 00:02:28.150
So when were troubleshooting,
we're doing a couple things.

50
00:02:28.150 --> 00:02:31.750
One, we're making sure that the user
is in the appropriate group, right?

51
00:02:31.750 --> 00:02:36.610
Because, we've had HR people for
years, since the business was opened.

52
00:02:36.610 --> 00:02:39.690
The HR people have access to that folder,
for example,

53
00:02:39.690 --> 00:02:41.140
that they're supposed to have access to.

54
00:02:41.140 --> 00:02:44.420
We hire a new HR person,
they can't get access.

55
00:02:44.420 --> 00:02:45.970
Well, what could be the problem?

56
00:02:45.970 --> 00:02:49.196
Well, most likely if all the other
HR people can still access it and

57
00:02:49.196 --> 00:02:50.349
the new person can't,

58
00:02:50.349 --> 00:02:54.053
that means that they haven't been put
into the correct groups yet, right?

59
00:02:54.053 --> 00:02:57.449
They haven't been added to the group
that gives them the permissions over

60
00:02:57.449 --> 00:02:58.560
the resource.

61
00:02:58.560 --> 00:03:02.680
So that's how a lot of the troubleshooting
is verifying group membership

62
00:03:02.680 --> 00:03:03.932
on a user account.

63
00:03:03.932 --> 00:03:07.990
And a simple command you can do like,
let's take look at my screen here.

64
00:03:07.990 --> 00:03:13.099
What I'm gonna do is I'm gonna open
up a Windows Explorer and we'll just

65
00:03:13.099 --> 00:03:18.840
kinda walk through some of the steps I
would use if I was troubleshooting access.

66
00:03:18.840 --> 00:03:23.704
So, I'm logged on I believe
here as Danielsan, and I am.

67
00:03:23.704 --> 00:03:24.740
There we go.

68
00:03:24.740 --> 00:03:26.255
Cuz he shared his password with me.

69
00:03:26.255 --> 00:03:28.130
[LAUGH]
>> I leave it underneath my keyboard

70
00:03:28.130 --> 00:03:30.890
on a sticky note,
that way I don't forget it.

71
00:03:30.890 --> 00:03:34.962
>> [LAUGH] Exactly, I try to teach
these guys but they don't listen.

72
00:03:34.962 --> 00:03:37.054
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] All right, so

73
00:03:37.054 --> 00:03:42.425
I'm gonna connect over to SBR01/docs,
all right.

74
00:03:42.425 --> 00:03:47.040
And oh no, I get the dreaded
cannot access the resource, right?

75
00:03:47.040 --> 00:03:50.060
Contact your network
administrator to request access.

76
00:03:50.060 --> 00:03:52.800
>> Now, Mike, this could be just
a straight up network issue, right?

77
00:03:52.800 --> 00:03:54.690
>> Yes.
>> If the network is busted and

78
00:03:54.690 --> 00:03:56.645
they're not able to access
it through the network,

79
00:03:56.645 --> 00:03:58.140
they're gonna get the same kind of error.

00:03:58.140 --> 00:04:02.110
But if you do take a look at that and
you realize the network's humming and

00:04:02.110 --> 00:04:04.140
drumming, then we're
moving into permissions.

82
00:04:04.140 --> 00:04:04.680
>> Absolutely.

83

What we could do if we thought it was
a network error, one of the first things

00:04:07.550 --> 00:04:11.910
we might do is pop open a Command Prompt

00:04:11.910 --> 00:04:17.010

00:04:17.010 --> 00:04:21.890
I'll get a request timed out instead of
a general failure or something like that.

87
00:04:21.890 --> 00:04:26.340
So that's a good indication that there's
probably a firewall blocking those pings,

88
00:04:26.340 --> 00:04:27.840
but I am talking to it.

89
00:04:27.840 --> 00:04:31.235
And in most corporate environments,
Ping is usually turned on so

90
00:04:31.235 --> 00:04:33.240
that I can do that network
connectivity test.

91
00:04:33.240 --> 00:04:37.400
So that'd be a great first step,
make sure the server is reachable.

92
00:04:37.400 --> 00:04:41.720
After that what I might to do,
cuz I'm going across the network

93
00:04:41.720 --> 00:04:45.210
to gain access to this resource,
I'm using a UNC path.

94
00:04:45.210 --> 00:04:48.720
So what I'm gonna do,
let's go over to the server itself and

95
00:04:48.720 --> 00:04:50.270
see what's going on here.

96
00:04:50.270 --> 00:04:53.855
If I open up File Explorer and
I find that Docs folder,

97
00:04:53.855 --> 00:04:58.040
then I can pull up its Properties,
and go over to the Sharing tab.

98
00:04:58.040 --> 00:04:59.490
And I can see that it is shared out,

00:04:59.490 --> 00:05:03.803
so that's a good sign, you know, at least

00:05:03.803 --> 00:05:09.050

00:05:09.050 --> 00:05:13.680
group has permissions, but I don't believe

00:05:13.680 --> 00:05:14.920

A command that we should be familiar with,

00:05:24.506 --> 00:05:29.300

00:05:29.300 --> 00:05:32.870
nowhere in here is it gonna show
that he's in the Executives group.

107
00:05:32.870 --> 00:05:34.960
So that's my first problem, right?

108
00:05:34.960 --> 00:05:40.060
Daniel's not in that list or any of the

109
00:05:40.060 --> 00:05:42.020
So let's see if we can fix that.

110
00:05:42.020 --> 00:05:45.005
We'll flip back over here to

00:05:45.005 --> 00:05:48.710
And somehow, you know, maybe something
got removed accidentally, or

00:05:48.710 --> 00:05:50.990
this is a new folder that got created and

00:05:50.990 --> 00:05:54.650

00:05:54.650 --> 00:05:57.670
We'll add the Host group,
and we'll go ahead and

115
00:05:57.670 --> 00:06:00.700
give him full control,
because we like our host.

116
00:06:00.700 --> 00:06:02.262
We trust our hosts around here.

117
00:06:02.262 --> 00:06:02.827
>> Stupid.

118
00:06:02.827 --> 00:06:04.260
>> Silly, silly.

119
00:06:04.260 --> 00:06:04.970
>> That guy's crazy.

120
00:06:04.970 --> 00:06:08.200
>> All right, so now it's shared out and

00:06:08.200 --> 00:06:12.968
we're gonna flip back over here to
Daniel's screen and we're gonna type

00:06:12.968 --> 00:06:17.860
in \\svr01\docs.

123
00:06:17.860 --> 00:06:20.670

124
00:06:20.670 --> 00:06:21.342
What the heck?

125
00:06:21.342 --> 00:06:24.642
>> Well now, Mike,
we just saw you put in the correct group.

126
00:06:24.642 --> 00:06:27.958
To say even full control over this,
over the share permissions,

127
00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:30.130
amd accessing it through a share.

128
00:06:30.130 --> 00:06:31.580
The hack is the problem?

129
00:06:31.580 --> 00:06:33.014
>> Yeah, well, we're gonna have
to go find out, aren't we?

130
00:06:33.014 --> 00:06:33.520
>> We are.

131
00:06:33.520 --> 00:06:35.460
>> Let's go see what's going on.

132
00:06:35.460 --> 00:06:39.160
If we flip back over here to the resource,
and we pull up its permissions,

133
00:06:39.160 --> 00:06:42.877
there's a couple of ways you could go
about trying to troubleshoot this.

134
00:06:42.877 --> 00:06:47.533
I, personally, I'm a little old school,
so I might go directly over here to

135
00:06:47.533 --> 00:06:51.850
these tabs and like we just did,
look at those share permissions.

136
00:06:51.850 --> 00:06:54.210
Because if you don't have share
permissions you can't reach out and

137
00:06:54.210 --> 00:06:57.330
get to the network or
get to the resource across the network.

138
00:06:57.330 --> 00:07:00.710
Well I can see Host has access,
full control, as Daniel said.

139
00:07:00.710 --> 00:07:04.060
And he's in that Host group so
we should be good to go there.

140
00:07:05.240 --> 00:07:07.660
The next thing I might do is go
over to the Security tab and

141
00:07:07.660 --> 00:07:09.820
look at my NTFS permissions.

142
00:07:09.820 --> 00:07:13.620
And, lo and behold, Creator,
Owner, System, Administrators.

143
00:07:13.620 --> 00:07:15.620
None of which Daniel belongs to, right?

144
00:07:15.620 --> 00:07:17.510
And, this is a key point.

145
00:07:17.510 --> 00:07:20.910
When we look at accessing
resources across the network, yes,

146
00:07:20.910 --> 00:07:24.160
you need share permissions to
reach out to that UNC path.

147
00:07:24.160 --> 00:07:27.270
You still need the appropriate
NTFS permissions

148
00:07:27.270 --> 00:07:28.760
to be able to connect to the resource.

149
00:07:28.760 --> 00:07:32.460
Remember, share permissions are only
checked when you access the resource

150
00:07:32.460 --> 00:07:33.400
as a share.

151
00:07:33.400 --> 00:07:37.664
In other words, when I use a UNC path or
a map network drive,

152
00:07:37.664 --> 00:07:40.325
when I'm going across the network.

153
00:07:40.325 --> 00:07:44.458
NTFS permissions are always checked,
whether I'm going across the network or

154
00:07:44.458 --> 00:07:48.469
whether I'm actually sitting at the
machine and interactively logged on and

155
00:07:48.469 --> 00:07:52.435
opening up File Explorer and
double-clicking on it that way.

156
00:07:52.435 --> 00:07:54.702
NTFS permissions are always checked so

157
00:07:54.702 --> 00:07:59.107
you can't get away without having NTFS
permission to access the resource.

158
00:07:59.107 --> 00:08:01.891
Now another tool I could
use here at this point.

159
00:08:01.891 --> 00:08:06.695
If I go into Advanced, there's my good,
old Effective access tab, all right?

160
00:08:06.695 --> 00:08:10.170
And so let's do that one more time to
make sure you guys saw where I went.

161
00:08:10.170 --> 00:08:14.130
I'm on the properties of the resource,
I'm on that Security tab, and

162
00:08:14.130 --> 00:08:15.620
I click Advanced.

163
00:08:15.620 --> 00:08:18.260
And then I'm gonna click
on Effective Access.

164
00:08:18.260 --> 00:08:19.863
And all I'm gonna do
is select Daniel here.

165
00:08:21.778 --> 00:08:24.880
All right,
see what kind of permissions he has.

166
00:08:24.880 --> 00:08:27.230
And I'll look at View effective access.

167

00:24:07.970 --> 00:24:12.838
remote locations connect on-premise,
off-premise, doesn't matter.

454
00:24:12.838 --> 00:24:14.330
All you need's the web browser.

455
00:24:14.330 --> 00:24:18.530
So keep in mind one of
the drawbacks to this one.

456
00:24:18.530 --> 00:24:21.410
Again, it all centers around
that Internet connection.

457
00:24:21.410 --> 00:24:25.420
But know the differences, know in
some of the scenarios that you would

458
00:24:25.420 --> 00:24:28.970
use these different solutions for
the exam.

459
00:24:28.970 --> 00:24:31.090
In case they set you up with a scenario,

460
00:24:31.090 --> 00:24:34.470
be able to differentiate which one you'll
use, and you should be doing good.

461
00:24:34.470 --> 00:24:35.100
>> All right, Wes.

462
00:24:35.100 --> 00:24:39.330
Well, thanks for this laundry list of
awesomeness that comes from Microsoft,

463
00:24:39.330 --> 00:24:41.110
giving us a list of benefits and

464
00:24:41.110 --> 00:24:43.955
features that we get with
our mobile device solutions.

465
00:24:43.955 --> 00:24:48.530
Connect those mobile devices, it's just
the world we live in, so we've gotta start

00:24:48.530 --> 00:24:52.086
supporting it, and Windows X does that and

00:24:52.086 --> 00:24:56.804
all the other great stuff we named today,
Office 365, as well as RemoteApp as well.

468
00:24:56.804 --> 00:25:00.319
All right, that being said, Wes,
it looks like we've wrapped up the show.

469
00:25:00.319 --> 00:25:04.893
I thank you so much for stopping by and
teaching our good folks, and even myself,

470
00:25:04.893 --> 00:25:06.900
all about these technologies.

471
00:25:06.900 --> 00:25:10.430
We appreciate you guys watching but
it is time to sign off.

472
00:25:10.430 --> 00:25:13.090
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.
