episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel walk you through the many different ways that you can access and share resources. They explain in detail how to create and manage shared folders and access to those shares as well as how to share a connected print device.
episodes.title: Configure Shared Resources
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.206 --> 00:00:10.206
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.919 --> 00:00:16.517
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another fantastic episode of IT Pro TV.

3
00:00:16.517 --> 00:00:17.920
I'm your host Daniel Lowery.

4
00:00:17.920 --> 00:00:19.790
Here with me today,
well it's Mike Rodrick.

5
00:00:19.790 --> 00:00:20.534
How's it going Mike?

6
00:00:20.534 --> 00:00:21.520
>> Oh, it's going great Daniel.

7
00:00:21.520 --> 00:00:26.320
I'm excited to be here because we're going
to be doing our Windows 10 shows and

00:00:26.320 --> 00:00:29.060
in this episode we're going
to be going into shares.

9
00:00:29.060 --> 00:00:30.390
A lot of different kinds of shares.

10
00:00:30.390 --> 00:00:33.293
Shared printers, shared folders,
shared home groups.

11
00:00:33.293 --> 00:00:34.290
>> We're back in kindergarten.

12
00:00:34.290 --> 00:00:36.696
We're learning how to share today,
ladies and gentleman.

13
00:00:36.696 --> 00:00:37.532
And hey, you know what?

00:00:37.532 --> 00:00:38.910
Sharing is a good thing.

15
00:00:38.910 --> 00:00:40.810
Especially when it comes to our computers.

16
00:00:40.810 --> 00:00:44.020
We want to be able to share not
necessarily just the resources, but

17
00:00:44.020 --> 00:00:46.790
some of the things that we have on them.

18
00:00:46.790 --> 00:00:50.360
Files, emails, things of that nature,
we'll be able to share this stuff out so

19
00:00:50.360 --> 00:00:53.960
that hey, if Mike needs that copy
of that document, not a problem.

20
00:00:53.960 --> 00:00:57.070
He can gain access to it even
if it's located on my machine.

21
00:00:57.070 --> 00:01:02.280
So we have a few different ways in which
we can do some sharing using Windows 10.

22
00:01:02.280 --> 00:01:03.740
And we're gonna explore those today and

23
00:01:03.740 --> 00:01:06.930
see how we can optimize that
to our own environments.

24
00:01:06.930 --> 00:01:09.600
Mikey, you've done a little
bit of sharing in your past.

25
00:01:09.600 --> 00:01:10.136
>> Once or twice.

26
00:01:10.136 --> 00:01:11.134
Sharing is caring.

27
00:01:11.134 --> 00:01:12.237
>> That's right, sharing is caring.

28
00:01:12.237 --> 00:01:13.909
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah,

29
00:01:13.909 --> 00:01:15.778
let's take a look at how we can
go about doing some sharing.

30
00:01:15.778 --> 00:01:19.449
As Daniel said, there's actually a few
different ways we can go about making

31
00:01:19.449 --> 00:01:23.570
things available to other people on
the network, sharing out these resources.

32
00:01:23.570 --> 00:01:25.690
So we're gonna explore a couple of them.

33
00:01:25.690 --> 00:01:30.161
And I wanna start by just talking about a
share and just making sure we're clear on

34
00:01:30.161 --> 00:01:34.627
what we mean, or if Microsoft in an exam,
or us here, when we say share something

35
00:01:34.627 --> 00:01:39.459
out, what we're really talking about is
making it available on the network, right.

36
00:01:39.459 --> 00:01:43.810
I've got stuff on my PC,
I want Daniel to be able to access it.

37
00:01:43.810 --> 00:01:46.530
Well, I could copy it to a thumb drive,
throw it over there,

38
00:01:46.530 --> 00:01:47.550
hope I don't hit him in the head.

39
00:01:47.550 --> 00:01:51.270
And he could plug it into his computer and
he could get access to that resource.

40
00:01:51.270 --> 00:01:54.130
If he makes changes to it, he's gonna
have to copy back to the thumb drive,

41
00:01:54.130 --> 00:01:57.190
he's gonna have to throw it back at me,
I gotta, that kind of thing.

42
00:01:57.190 --> 00:02:00.300
It's just not that easy or
it's not convenient.

43
00:02:00.300 --> 00:02:03.010
Where as sharing something is
making it available on the network.

44
00:02:03.010 --> 00:02:07.040
Hey, my computer's hooked up to the same
computer Daniel's is, why don't I

45
00:02:07.040 --> 00:02:11.930
just allow him to come across the network
and get access to that resource?

46
00:02:11.930 --> 00:02:14.770
And that's what we're talking
about when we talk about sharing.

47
00:02:14.770 --> 00:02:17.470
And one of the big things that Microsoft's
gonna call out on the exam is to make

48
00:02:17.470 --> 00:02:20.630
sure we understand share permissions,
right.

49
00:02:20.630 --> 00:02:24.040
And we've got other episodes where
we deal with NTFS permissions.

50
00:02:24.040 --> 00:02:26.540
I'm gonna mention those a couple of
times in here bit we're not really

51
00:02:26.540 --> 00:02:27.580
going over them.

52
00:02:27.580 --> 00:02:29.683
This one's focused on sharing and

53
00:02:29.683 --> 00:02:33.463
it is a different set of permissions
when it comes to sharing.

54
00:02:33.463 --> 00:02:37.021
They're not the same as NTFS, so
we've gotta make sure we understand them,

55
00:02:37.021 --> 00:02:40.280
what they mean, how we apply them,
and all that good stuff.

56
00:02:40.280 --> 00:02:43.850
So let's simply start by I've got
our Windows 10 machine here, and

57
00:02:43.850 --> 00:02:45.479
I'm gonna open up good old File Explorer.

58
00:02:47.430 --> 00:02:49.590
And I'm going to maximize that for us.

59
00:02:49.590 --> 00:02:54.480
Navigate over to my C drive, and
I'm simply going to create a folder.

60
00:02:55.720 --> 00:02:59.770
And I'm just gonna call it Data or
something like that, right.

61
00:02:59.770 --> 00:03:03.190
So now I have a folder on my machine,
but only way anybody could

62
00:03:03.190 --> 00:03:08.208
access that folder at this point would
be to have a log-on on this machine.

63
00:03:08.208 --> 00:03:09.605
If they could come sit down and

64
00:03:09.605 --> 00:03:12.790
log-on to this machine,
they could gain access to the folder.

65
00:03:12.790 --> 00:03:15.420
Anybody on the network, though,
is not gonna be able to access that.

66
00:03:15.420 --> 00:03:16.400
So how do I make it available?

67
00:03:16.400 --> 00:03:18.800
How do I say hey Daniel,
come check out this folder.

68
00:03:18.800 --> 00:03:21.290
It's got some good stuff in there
I want you to take a look at.

69
00:03:21.290 --> 00:03:24.670
I have to share it,
share it with the network, right?

70
00:03:24.670 --> 00:03:27.030
And that's what's gonna make
it available to the network.

71
00:03:27.030 --> 00:03:31.100
And as I said, there's several
different ways we can go about sharing.

72
00:03:31.100 --> 00:03:33.060
So I'm gonna show you a few of them.

73
00:03:33.060 --> 00:03:34.990
The first one,
I'm gonna right click on this and

74
00:03:34.990 --> 00:03:39.230
in that Context menu,
there's a Share With option, right?

75
00:03:39.230 --> 00:03:43.488
And if I go over here, I could stop
sharing it if was already being shared or

76
00:03:43.488 --> 00:03:45.288
I can choose specific people.

77
00:03:45.288 --> 00:03:46.550
So this one is a shared get, right?

78
00:03:46.550 --> 00:03:48.190
You just saw me create it.

79
00:03:48.190 --> 00:03:50.209
So now I wanna make it
available to the network.

80
00:03:50.209 --> 00:03:52.800
So I'm gonna say specific people.

81
00:03:52.800 --> 00:03:55.320
And I get this handy dandy little wizard.

82
00:03:55.320 --> 00:03:58.470
And the first thing I do is I
choose who I want to share it with.

83
00:03:58.470 --> 00:04:00.700
Now there's the everyone
group listed there.

84
00:04:00.700 --> 00:04:03.690
And remember the Everyone
group means everyone.

85
00:04:03.690 --> 00:04:05.210
This could be guest accounts,

86
00:04:05.210 --> 00:04:08.667
and things like that, so just keep
that in mind when you use Everyone.

87
00:04:08.667 --> 00:04:10.275
Like in a corporate environment,

88
00:04:10.275 --> 00:04:13.490
I'll tell you a better option is to
use the authenticated users group

89
00:04:13.490 --> 00:04:17.661
because that's going to include everybody
that you're probably thinking of, right?

90
00:04:17.661 --> 00:04:20.830
All your co-workers,
the IT staff, things like that.

91
00:04:20.830 --> 00:04:24.680
Everybody that has an account
in your active directory domain,

92
00:04:24.680 --> 00:04:29.030
usually a better option unless it's
a public resource or something like that.

93
00:04:29.030 --> 00:04:30.450
So I could choose Everyone,

94
00:04:30.450 --> 00:04:34.126
but if I'm not wanting to use the Everyone
group I can choose Find People.

95
00:04:34.126 --> 00:04:38.597
It opens up a common dialog box that we
have probably seen in several shows, and

96
00:04:38.597 --> 00:04:40.720
I can browse and find whoever I want.

97
00:04:40.720 --> 00:04:42.973
I'll do Authenticated Users.

98
00:04:42.973 --> 00:04:46.150
Remember, Authenticated Users
includes everybody that's logged in.

99
00:04:46.150 --> 00:04:47.630
Users and computers, for that matter.

100
00:04:47.630 --> 00:04:49.160
And then, we'll click OK.

101
00:04:50.790 --> 00:04:54.099
And then, for the permissions,
through this wizard, I get a choice.

102
00:04:54.099 --> 00:04:57.152
I've got either Read, or Read and Write.

103
00:04:57.152 --> 00:05:00.307
All right, and I'll go ahead and
for this first one,

104
00:05:00.307 --> 00:05:03.900
let's just say we want them to
be able to read this resource.

105
00:05:03.900 --> 00:05:07.440
So we'll choose Read and
I'll click, Share.

106
00:05:07.440 --> 00:05:10.750
And now it's gonna ask me and I'm not an
administrator on this machine evidently.

107
00:05:10.750 --> 00:05:14.980
So I will real quickly fill in
an administrator user name and password.

108
00:05:16.860 --> 00:05:18.439
Which is a good learning point there.

109
00:05:18.439 --> 00:05:21.682
You do have to be an admin on
the local machine at least in order

110
00:05:21.682 --> 00:05:23.700
to create that share.

111
00:05:23.700 --> 00:05:25.120
And there you go, my share is created,

112
00:05:25.120 --> 00:05:29.620
and it gives me a handy link here,
shows me what the UNC path is gonna be.

113
00:05:29.620 --> 00:05:32.455
Remember, UNC,
universal naming convention.

114
00:05:32.455 --> 00:05:34.696
Backslash, backslash,
name of the computer.

115
00:05:34.696 --> 00:05:37.630
Backslash, name of the share, right?

116
00:05:37.630 --> 00:05:42.460
And I can email this to somebody,
or copy and paste it, text it,

117
00:05:42.460 --> 00:05:46.520
or what have you, so that they can
now get access to that folder.

118
00:05:46.520 --> 00:05:47.660
I'll go ahead and click Done, all right?

119
00:05:49.470 --> 00:05:54.760
And if I flip over to my server here and
open up File Explorer,

120
00:05:54.760 --> 00:06:02.390
I should be able to go up in my address
bar //client100/ and there's my share.

121
00:06:03.490 --> 00:06:04.181
And now I'm connected.

122
00:06:04.181 --> 00:06:05.968
Now, its empty I didn't
put anything in it.

123
00:06:05.968 --> 00:06:10.728
And I only gave myself I gave everybody
read so let's see what it says.

124
00:06:10.728 --> 00:06:12.324
Because I'm an administrator,

125
00:06:12.324 --> 00:06:15.290
I'm connecting as an administrator
it is gonna let me write.

126
00:06:15.290 --> 00:06:18.448
That was a separate set of
permissions listed over there.

127
00:06:18.448 --> 00:06:19.609
So there's my share.

128
00:06:19.609 --> 00:06:21.188
That's the basic way.

129
00:06:21.188 --> 00:06:23.576
Now that wizard there Daniel,
that's what I call it, and

130
00:06:23.576 --> 00:06:25.660
it's called the Basic Sharing Wizard.

131
00:06:25.660 --> 00:06:28.662
And it's a very easy one to go through for
any end user.

132
00:06:28.662 --> 00:06:32.913
If somebody, Joe office worker, wants
to share something with somebody else,

133
00:06:32.913 --> 00:06:35.111
it's quick, it's dirty, it's easy.

134
00:06:35.111 --> 00:06:37.073
That doesn't ask him a lot of questions.

135
00:06:37.073 --> 00:06:39.960
Makes it very simple for them to do.

136
00:06:39.960 --> 00:06:44.310
But what we've gotta remember is that when
you connect to a resource on an NTFS file

137
00:06:44.310 --> 00:06:48.485
system, there's another set of
permissions that's always being checked.

138
00:06:48.485 --> 00:06:50.840
And that's NTFS permissions, right?

139
00:06:50.840 --> 00:06:53.670
Those are always checked,
whether you access the resource locally,

140
00:06:53.670 --> 00:06:57.680
like at the actual computer or whether
you go across the network to get to that

141
00:06:57.680 --> 00:07:01.630
resource, NTFS permissions
are always checked.

142
00:07:01.630 --> 00:07:06.180
So when you share something out,
you have to set the share permissions and

143
00:07:06.180 --> 00:07:07.470
the NTFS permissions.

144
00:07:07.470 --> 00:07:08.477
You have to set both.

145
00:07:08.477 --> 00:07:10.497
NTFS always checked.

146
00:07:10.497 --> 00:07:15.410
Share permissions only checked when you
go across the network to get to it.

147
00:07:15.410 --> 00:07:17.320
In other words if I gave you.

148
00:07:17.320 --> 00:07:20.590
Let's see how I could say this.

149
00:07:20.590 --> 00:07:29.395
If you were to have NTFS full control but
only share read permissions.

150
00:07:29.395 --> 00:07:33.375
Well, if you sit down locally and
access it, you're going to have

151
00:07:33.375 --> 00:07:37.805
full control because only NTFS is
checked you have NTFS full control.

152
00:07:37.805 --> 00:07:41.293
If you go across the network to get
to that share, both are checked.

153
00:07:41.293 --> 00:07:45.781
NTFS permissions, but you have to have
full control and shared permissions,

154
00:07:45.781 --> 00:07:47.625
which I said you only have read.

155
00:07:47.625 --> 00:07:52.543
When you go across the network like that,
you're going to combine NTFS and share.

156
00:07:52.543 --> 00:07:56.709
Permission and
it's the most restrictive of the two.

157
00:07:56.709 --> 00:08:01.340
NTFS full control share read,
which one's more restrictive?

158
00:08:01.340 --> 00:08:02.070
>> Share read.

159
00:08:02.070 --> 00:08:05.250
>> Share read, so you're gonna end
up with just read permissions.

160
00:08:05.250 --> 00:08:06.140
So in other words,

161
00:08:06.140 --> 00:08:09.540
if you go across the network to get
to that folder, you could only read.

162
00:08:09.540 --> 00:08:13.220
But if you have sat down locally at the
machine, you'd actually have full control,

163
00:08:13.220 --> 00:08:17.330
because share permissions aren't checked
if you're not going across the network.

164
00:08:17.330 --> 00:08:21.155
So only when you go across the network,
a UNC path, a map network drive,

165
00:08:21.155 --> 00:08:24.502
that's when those share permissions
are gonna get kicked in.

166
00:08:24.502 --> 00:08:28.200
And you might think to yourself, well
Mike, you never said the NTFS permissions.

167
00:08:28.200 --> 00:08:30.780
You just said you had to do both,
and you did not do it.

168
00:08:30.780 --> 00:08:32.320
And you still got access.

169
00:08:32.320 --> 00:08:34.900
That's because of that
basic sharing wizard.

170
00:08:34.900 --> 00:08:38.730
What that basic share wizard does is it,
all right, this is probably somebody

171
00:08:38.730 --> 00:08:43.720
that's not an IT person creating a share,
you set the share permissions and

172
00:08:43.720 --> 00:08:48.170
we'll go ahead and make matching NTFS
permissions for you in the background.

173
00:08:48.170 --> 00:08:51.480
That way, Joe Office Worker doesn't say,
hey Bob, I shared this out.

174
00:08:51.480 --> 00:08:52.510
You should try to get to it now.

175
00:08:52.510 --> 00:08:53.670
I can't get to it.

176
00:08:53.670 --> 00:08:54.960
I don't know what's wrong.

177
00:08:54.960 --> 00:08:55.850
That kind of thing, right?

178
00:08:55.850 --> 00:08:57.310
So, it makes it very easy.

179
00:08:57.310 --> 00:08:58.421
In fact, let's go look.

180
00:08:58.421 --> 00:09:02.940
[COUGH] If I pull up the properties for
this folder and go to the security,

181
00:09:02.940 --> 00:09:08.050
you'll see authenticated users and
they have read and

182
00:09:08.050 --> 00:09:12.960
execute, list contents, and read because
I set that share permission read.

183
00:09:12.960 --> 00:09:14.910
It took care of the NTFS for me.

184
00:09:14.910 --> 00:09:16.080
So that's pretty handy.

185
00:09:16.080 --> 00:09:19.180
Like I said, that's what makes it easy for
the end user because they don't have to

186
00:09:19.180 --> 00:09:24.175
understand all that other stuff about
what is an NT fee sepa permission right.

187
00:09:24.175 --> 00:09:27.630
>> [LAUGH] Yeah totally anybody that's
ever started to try to work with

188
00:09:27.630 --> 00:09:32.260
permissions it can get a little hinky
pretty quickly because you're like okay so

189
00:09:32.260 --> 00:09:35.475
when I get the most restrictive now
which one's more restrictive than this?

190
00:09:35.475 --> 00:09:40.025
And for that basic user, that gets very,
very difficult and very complex for them.

191
00:09:40.025 --> 00:09:42.305
So it's nice that Microsoft has said,
you know what?

192
00:09:42.305 --> 00:09:45.455
We'll make this easy for our basic users.

193
00:09:45.455 --> 00:09:46.765
They just wanna share a folder out?

194
00:09:46.765 --> 00:09:47.685
Not a problem.

195
00:09:47.685 --> 00:09:49.705
There's a nice basic sharing option.

196
00:09:49.705 --> 00:09:51.385
I need to share this folder.

197
00:09:51.385 --> 00:09:54.270
I just say, I just need to share it, and
here's the people I need to share it with.

198
00:09:54.270 --> 00:09:58.330
And then, based on what permission levels
you give it at that point it time,

199
00:09:58.330 --> 00:10:01.870
it realizes, okay, that's what you need
to do, I'm gonna go ahead and set that.

200
00:10:01.870 --> 00:10:03.648
You are an advanced user, though,

201
00:10:03.648 --> 00:10:07.028
there is a cool little trick to this
that I actually learned from Mr.

202
00:10:07.028 --> 00:10:10.251
Pezet, imagine that,
something brilliant that Don has done.

203
00:10:10.251 --> 00:10:16.710

00:03:33.150 --> 00:03:37.020
Even if that means creating a group,
putting one user in the group, and

71
00:03:37.020 --> 00:03:38.710
then assigning that group permissions.

72
00:03:38.710 --> 00:03:40.530
You might think,
why in the heck would I do that?

73
00:03:40.530 --> 00:03:42.840
Why not just give that person permissions?

74
00:03:42.840 --> 00:03:44.510
Because today it's one person.

75
00:03:44.510 --> 00:03:47.550
Tomorrow, next week, next month,
it could be ten, 20, 50 people.

76
00:03:47.550 --> 00:03:51.920
And you don't wanna add 50 people to this
access control list and have to scroll,

77
00:03:51.920 --> 00:03:53.890
scroll, scroll to find anything.

78
00:03:53.890 --> 00:03:55.960
All right.
You wanna add the group.

79
00:03:55.960 --> 00:03:59.780
And now I can control the permissions
by just adding removing members of that

80
00:03:59.780 --> 00:04:02.640
group, and that access control
list itself doesn't change.

81
00:04:02.640 --> 00:04:04.070
There's a lot more to it.

82
00:04:04.070 --> 00:04:06.080
We'll talk more about
that in our server class,

83
00:04:06.080 --> 00:04:09.540
as far as using Microsoft's
strategy of using groups.

84
00:04:09.540 --> 00:04:11.930
Just kinda put that in the back
of your head at this point.

85
00:04:11.930 --> 00:04:16.320
I really want to avoid adding users
directly to the access control list,

86
00:04:16.320 --> 00:04:17.950
I'd much rather use groups.

87
00:04:17.950 --> 00:04:20.910
Second thing we need to talk about
is the permissions themselves.

88
00:04:20.910 --> 00:04:23.910
So let's take a look at what
permissions are available.

89
00:04:23.910 --> 00:04:28.670
If we scroll down here, you see I've got
Full control, Modify, Read & Execute,

90
00:04:28.670 --> 00:04:33.800
List folder contents, and Read, and
then Write, sorry, I almost forgot Write.

91
00:04:33.800 --> 00:04:35.680
And then Special Permissions.

92
00:04:35.680 --> 00:04:39.030
And what I'm going to do is I'm
going to uncheck everything here.

93
00:04:39.030 --> 00:04:40.970
I want to show you how this works.

94
00:04:40.970 --> 00:04:43.660
There's a little thing in here that
confuses people the first time

95
00:04:43.660 --> 00:04:44.640
they look at it.

96
00:04:44.640 --> 00:04:46.460
Read is simply that.

97
00:04:46.460 --> 00:04:50.920
If you have read permission over a file
then you can open that file up and

98
00:04:50.920 --> 00:04:53.550
you can read the contents of the file,
but that's all you can do.

99
00:04:53.550 --> 00:04:57.070
You can't make changes, you can't
do anything else to that document.

100
00:04:57.070 --> 00:04:59.050
All right?
Notice when I check Read,

101
00:04:59.050 --> 00:05:00.570
nothing else gets selected.

102
00:05:00.570 --> 00:05:02.910
That's its own individual permission.

103
00:05:02.910 --> 00:05:06.450
The one that confuses people
a lot of times, or is weird,

104
00:05:06.450 --> 00:05:08.430
is this Write permission.

105
00:05:08.430 --> 00:05:13.490
Write permission gives you the ability to
write, obviously, depending on what it is,

106
00:05:13.490 --> 00:05:14.620
if it's a folder, and

107
00:05:14.620 --> 00:05:18.330
you have write permission, you can
create new documents inside that folder.

108
00:05:18.330 --> 00:05:22.410
If you have write permissions over a file,
then you can open up that file and

109
00:05:22.410 --> 00:05:24.190
you can change the contents of the file.

110
00:05:24.190 --> 00:05:25.290
All right?

111
00:05:25.290 --> 00:05:27.520
You cannot delete the file itself,

112
00:05:27.520 --> 00:05:31.630
you could backspace up over all the
content and save it as an empty file, but

113
00:05:31.630 --> 00:05:35.180
the object, the file itself with write
permissions, you cannot delete it.

114
00:05:35.180 --> 00:05:35.870
All right?

115
00:05:35.870 --> 00:05:39.140
Also notice when I check Write,
you don't get any other permission.

116
00:05:39.140 --> 00:05:43.790
Most people think, hey, if I give you a
write, you've got to have read permission.

117
00:05:43.790 --> 00:05:44.380
Wrong.

118
00:05:44.380 --> 00:05:46.690
I can give you write permission and
not read.

119
00:05:46.690 --> 00:05:50.770
It's a rare thing that I would ever
do that, but you can do it and

120
00:05:50.770 --> 00:05:52.610
it's important that we understand that.

121
00:05:52.610 --> 00:05:56.690
The only scenario, Daniel, that I've ever
come up with that might make sense is

122
00:05:56.690 --> 00:06:00.090
let's say, I'm taking some
online classes and I have to

123
00:06:00.090 --> 00:06:04.080
upload my homework using FTP to this
folder that the instructor has set up.

124
00:06:04.080 --> 00:06:06.800
All right, I need write
permissions over that folder, so

125
00:06:06.800 --> 00:06:10.260
I can upload my document there,
my homework that I'm supposed to turn in.

126
00:06:10.260 --> 00:06:13.480
But he doesn't want me to be able
to read other people's homework,

127
00:06:13.480 --> 00:06:15.340
the ones that they've already uploaded.

128
00:06:15.340 --> 00:06:15.920
Right?
So

129
00:06:15.920 --> 00:06:18.610
he would give me write
permissions over the folder, but

130
00:06:18.610 --> 00:06:20.220
he wouldn't give me read permission.

131
00:06:20.220 --> 00:06:22.810
So that way I couldn't look
at other people's' files and

132
00:06:22.810 --> 00:06:24.690
try to copy their homework or
something like that.

133
00:06:24.690 --> 00:06:27.940
So again, rare thing, but
just know that it's possible.

134
00:06:27.940 --> 00:06:31.530
>> Yeah, the only thing I could think of
is maybe if you had a script that ran as

135
00:06:31.530 --> 00:06:34.860
a backup, since all it's doing is
backing up, just writing files.

136
00:06:34.860 --> 00:06:36.910
It doesn't need access to read them.

137
00:06:36.910 --> 00:06:38.060
It just needs access to write them.

138
00:06:38.060 --> 00:06:39.660
So maybe if you're doing some scripting,

139
00:06:39.660 --> 00:06:43.320
that write only permission might
come into play from time to time.

140
00:06:43.320 --> 00:06:44.850
>> Yeah, very good example.

141
00:06:44.850 --> 00:06:47.640
All right, so the next thing,
we'll uncheck Write, and

142
00:06:47.640 --> 00:06:50.960
we'll take a look at List
folder contents only shows up

143
00:06:50.960 --> 00:06:54.160
if you've right click on a folder and
chosen Properties, right?

144
00:06:54.160 --> 00:06:59.190
It wouldn't be on a file,
because there's not folder contents.

145
00:06:59.190 --> 00:07:00.457
And that's what lets you browse.

146
00:07:00.457 --> 00:07:04.180
If I had List folder contents,
when I double click on that folder,

147
00:07:04.180 --> 00:07:06.960
I can see the files that
exist inside that folder.

148
00:07:06.960 --> 00:07:08.980
I don't get,
that does not build on anything either.

149
00:07:10.040 --> 00:07:12.250
Then there's Read & execute.

150
00:07:12.250 --> 00:07:13.940
And Read & execute does build.

151
00:07:13.940 --> 00:07:18.075
Notice if I select Read & execute I
also get List folder contents and Read.

152
00:07:18.075 --> 00:07:22.360
And if I try to take any of these away,
Read & execute goes away.

153
00:07:22.360 --> 00:07:26.760
So Read & execute builds on top
of List folder contents and Read.

154
00:07:26.760 --> 00:07:29.260
And you need this if you
wanna run something.

155
00:07:29.260 --> 00:07:33.050
If there's an executable or a command
script or something like that, and

156
00:07:33.050 --> 00:07:34.020
you want to double click on it and

157
00:07:34.020 --> 00:07:37.350
have it run, you need Read & execute,
not just Read.

158
00:07:37.350 --> 00:07:39.820
Read would let you see it there,
but you couldn't run it.

159
00:07:39.820 --> 00:07:42.480
So Read & execute to execute something.

160
00:07:42.480 --> 00:07:44.120
I'll uncheck all those.

161
00:07:44.120 --> 00:07:46.244
And let's try Modify.

162
00:07:46.244 --> 00:07:50.210
Modify, notice,
gives you almost everything else.

163
00:07:50.210 --> 00:07:53.530
Read & execute, List folder contents,
Read and Write.

164
00:07:53.530 --> 00:07:55.640
A lot of people now get confused here.

165
00:07:55.640 --> 00:07:59.095
What's the difference between Write and
Modify.

166
00:07:59.095 --> 00:08:02.159
Well, one,
Modify gives you the other permissions.

167
00:08:02.159 --> 00:08:03.252
Right, it builds.

168
00:08:03.252 --> 00:08:07.449
But the big difference we need to be aware
of is the fact that Modify Lets you delete

169
00:08:07.449 --> 00:08:08.511
the object itself.

170
00:08:08.511 --> 00:08:13.090
Whereas, write would let you delete
the contents, but not the file.

171
00:08:13.090 --> 00:08:15.200
Modify lets you delete the file.

172
00:08:15.200 --> 00:08:18.252
So that's the big permission
you pick up when you get modify

173
00:08:18.252 --> 00:08:21.194
permissions is the ability
to delete the object itself.

174
00:08:21.194 --> 00:08:25.854
All right, and then we'll uncheck, and if
I uncheck any of this, modify goes away,

175
00:08:25.854 --> 00:08:27.490
right cuz it builds on those.

176
00:08:29.180 --> 00:08:31.040
And then the last one is full control.

177
00:08:32.550 --> 00:08:35.590
And of course,
that gives you everything as well.

178
00:08:35.590 --> 00:08:39.395
Full control doesn't give you
a whole lot more than modify.

179
00:08:39.395 --> 00:08:41.400
Modifiy is a pretty powerful permission.

180
00:08:41.400 --> 00:08:45.880
If I can delete the object, it doesn't
get much more powerful than that.

181
00:08:45.880 --> 00:08:48.050
Full control does you give
you a few things though.

182
00:08:48.050 --> 00:08:51.690
It gives you the ability to modify
the access control list itself.

183
00:08:51.690 --> 00:08:54.230
Like if I have modify,
I could delete the file.

184
00:08:54.230 --> 00:08:57.029
But I couldn't right-click on the file,
go to the Security tab, and

185
00:08:57.029 --> 00:08:59.380
change what permissions people have.

186
00:08:59.380 --> 00:09:03.052
Full control gives me the ability to
modify the access control list itself.

187
00:09:03.052 --> 00:09:06.965
It also gives me the ability to
take ownership of an object,

188
00:09:06.965 --> 00:09:12.700
which could be important depending on, I
don't know, changing ownership on a file.

189
00:09:12.700 --> 00:09:16.910
If somebody, let's say Daniel made
a company phone list document.

190
00:09:18.030 --> 00:09:18.970
Well he created it.

191
00:09:18.970 --> 00:09:21.690
He's now the creator owner of that, and

192
00:09:21.690 --> 00:09:24.760
the creator owner's a special
group that gets full control.

193
00:09:24.760 --> 00:09:27.280
So Daniel could at any
time delete that file.

194
00:09:27.280 --> 00:09:28.090
He could change.

195
00:09:28.090 --> 00:09:29.828
He could say, I'm mad at Mike.

196
00:09:29.828 --> 00:09:32.119
I don't want him to have
permissions over this, and

197
00:09:32.119 --> 00:09:35.890
I'm gonna take his permissions away
cuz creator owner has full control.

198
00:09:35.890 --> 00:09:39.435
If Daniel ever leaves or something like
that, that could also pose a problem.

199
00:09:39.435 --> 00:09:43.316
So sometimes we'll switch
the owner to the admins group, and

200
00:09:43.316 --> 00:09:47.812
you need full control to be able to
change who the owner is of a document.

201
00:09:47.812 --> 00:09:50.040
All right, so
those are the basic permissions.

202
00:09:50.040 --> 00:09:53.350
These are what we call our
standard NTFS permissions.

203
00:09:53.350 --> 00:09:57.280
Down at the bottom, there's this Special
permissions down here, right, and

204
00:09:57.280 --> 00:09:59.160
notice I can't check it.

205
00:09:59.160 --> 00:10:01.090
And what I'm gonna do is
I'm gonna go ahead and

206
00:10:01.090 --> 00:10:03.030
apply these changes that I've done so far.

207
00:10:04.220 --> 00:10:07.520
And I'll tell you that 99% of the time,
these standard permissions are all you

208
00:10:07.520 --> 00:10:12.250
need, read, write, modify, full control,
list folder contents, read and execute.

209
00:10:13.270 --> 00:10:17.070
Occasionally I might need
a little more granular control.

210
00:10:17.070 --> 00:10:19.710
And that's where I need to
click this Advanced button.

211
00:10:19.710 --> 00:10:25.980
And then I can come in here,
and I can go to the Add button.

212
00:10:25.980 --> 00:10:29.740
And let's select a principal,
and I'm gonna add another group,

213
00:10:29.740 --> 00:10:31.360
the Developers group here.

214
00:10:33.170 --> 00:10:35.953
And down below, over here on the left,

215
00:10:35.953 --> 00:10:38.750
or on the right,
I can't tell my left from my right.

216
00:10:38.750 --> 00:10:42.250
I'll click Show advanced permissions,
right.

217
00:10:42.250 --> 00:10:42.920
I'll try to click it.

218
00:10:42.920 --> 00:10:43.482
There we go.
And

219
00:10:43.482 --> 00:10:46.169
notice I have a lot more
permissions than I did on that

220
00:10:46.169 --> 00:10:48.130
standard access control list.

221
00:10:48.130 --> 00:10:51.490
Basically, what was one permission,
becomes multiple.

222
00:10:51.490 --> 00:10:53.930
It breaks it down into
more granular control.

223
00:10:53.930 --> 00:10:58.020
Like read, for example, is one check
mark on the access control list.

224
00:10:58.020 --> 00:11:02.025
But if I do my special permissions or
Advanced permissions,

225
00:11:02.025 --> 00:11:07.455
read becomes Read data, Read attributes,
and Read extended attributes.

226
00:11:07.455 --> 00:11:10.555
Write is one permission on
the standard permissions.

227
00:11:10.555 --> 00:11:14.460
In here it's Write data,
Append data, Write attributes,

228
00:11:14.460 --> 00:11:16.470
Write extended attributes.

229
00:11:16.470 --> 00:11:21.010
So if there was ever a reason that you
wanted them to be able to read the data

230
00:11:21.010 --> 00:11:25.570
but not the attributes for the data,
you could come in here and uncheck those.

231
00:11:25.570 --> 00:11:27.680
So if you ever need to break
the permissions down into more

232
00:11:27.680 --> 00:11:30.850
granular control,
special permissions are the way to go.

233
00:11:30.850 --> 00:11:35.130
Now if I've changed these special
permissions like this, I'll click OK and

234
00:11:35.130 --> 00:11:36.420
OK there.

235
00:11:36.420 --> 00:11:40.698
And I'll click OK and
then pull the Properties back up so

236
00:11:40.698 --> 00:11:44.168
those changes are apparent
in my dialog box.

237
00:11:44.168 --> 00:11:48.500
Go back over here to Security,
and I look at that dev team.

238
00:11:48.500 --> 00:11:51.350
Notice it doesn't look like
they have any permissions.

239
00:11:51.350 --> 00:11:53.060
But it does say they
have special permissions.

240
00:11:53.060 --> 00:11:55.900
And the only way to see what permissions
they would have would be to, again,

241
00:11:55.900 --> 00:11:57.580
go into Advanced.

242
00:11:57.580 --> 00:12:02.950
Come in here and take a look at the dev
team and Edit, and show those again.

243
00:12:02.950 --> 00:12:04.263
Just Special permissions there,

244
00:12:04.263 --> 00:12:06.915
I'd have to click the Show
advanced permissions to see it.

245
00:12:06.915 --> 00:12:08.174
Now Daniel, I don't know about you.

246
00:12:08.174 --> 00:12:10.514
I've never in the 12 years
I've been doing this,

247
00:12:10.514 --> 00:12:14.305
needed to break down permissions that
much, but it's good to know they're there.

248
00:12:14.305 --> 00:12:15.855
>> Yeah, it is good to know they're there.

249
00:12:15.855 --> 00:12:19.285
They're definitely going to test
you about this on the exam.

250
00:12:19.285 --> 00:12:23.291
But right, and as Mike said in
practicality there's rarely been a time

251
00:12:23.291 --> 00:12:26.915
that I can remember that I needed
to actually make some changes.

252
00:12:26.915 --> 00:12:27.704
It's actually,

253
00:12:27.704 --> 00:12:31.570
I can't even think of a time that I needed
to make special permissions changes.

254
00:12:31.570 --> 00:12:32.140
Like Mike said,

255
00:12:32.140 --> 00:12:36.590
normally just sticking right there in

00:12:36.590 --> 00:12:40.930
the object you're working with will do you

00:12:40.930 --> 00:12:43.720
The only time I really ever go in

00:12:43.720 --> 00:12:44.750

00:12:44.750 --> 00:12:47.720
Sometimes, you have

00:12:47.720 --> 00:12:50.420

00:12:50.420 --> 00:12:52.990
And they're no longer there,

that's when you gotta take ownership of

00:12:57.532 --> 00:13:00.689
But special permissions,
other than knowing why they're there and

00:13:00.689 --> 00:13:01.677
how they're there.

00:13:01.677 --> 00:13:02.309
And maybe,

267
00:13:02.309 --> 00:13:06.167
if you are really adept at understanding

00:13:06.167 --> 00:13:10.292
you can gain a little extra control and

269
00:13:10.292 --> 00:13:11.139
>> Yeah, absolutely.

270
00:13:11.139 --> 00:13:15.627
And that's why they're there, is if I ever
have the need to do that granular control,

271
00:13:15.627 --> 00:13:16.558
and maybe you do.

00:13:16.558 --> 00:13:20.193
Or maybe some application needs just

00:13:20.193 --> 00:13:23.172
you don't want to give it too many or

274
00:13:23.172 --> 00:13:25.848
All right, so the next thing we're
gonna talk about is called inheritance.

275
00:13:25.848 --> 00:13:29.377
And one of the great things about
NTFS is that permissions inherit.

276
00:13:29.377 --> 00:13:32.405
In other words,
if I set permissions at one level,

277
00:13:32.405 --> 00:13:36.360
those permissions then inherit
down to everything inside there.

278
00:13:36.360 --> 00:13:41.590
Like if I set the permissions on a folder,
then all the files inside that folder,

279
00:13:41.590 --> 00:13:42.810
all the subfolders,

280
00:13:42.810 --> 00:13:46.650
the files inside those subfolders,
those permissions will inherit down.

281
00:13:46.650 --> 00:13:47.490
And that's a good thing.

282
00:13:47.490 --> 00:13:51.070
We always try to apply
the permissions as high up as I can.

283
00:13:51.070 --> 00:13:53.440
If there's a folder with
100 documents in it,

284
00:13:53.440 --> 00:13:57.270
I don't wanna right-click on each document
one at a time and change permissions.

285
00:13:57.270 --> 00:14:00.894
I can do it at the folder level and
let inheritance do the work for me, right,

286
00:14:00.894 --> 00:14:04.510
let it take those permissions down
to all the objects inside there.

287
00:14:04.510 --> 00:14:05.580
And that is by default.

288
00:14:05.580 --> 00:14:10.810
When you set permissions like that, NTFS
permissions, they are going to inherit.

289
00:14:10.810 --> 00:14:14.614
For example, I'm going to come over
here to this Sales folder, and

00:14:14.614 --> 00:14:17.036

00:14:17.036 --> 00:14:21.320
Now, inside Sales, before I do that,

00:14:21.320 --> 00:14:25.110
And I'm gonna pull up the Properties for

And if I go to the Security tab,

00:14:26.730 --> 00:14:32.710
you'll see that in this list I do not have

295
00:14:32.710 --> 00:14:33.819
They're not in that list.

296
00:14:33.819 --> 00:14:36.340
So I'm gonna cancel that.

297
00:14:36.340 --> 00:14:41.586
Go back up one level,
right-click on Sales > Properties.

298
00:14:41.586 --> 00:14:45.206
And then I'm going to go over
to that Security tab, and

00:14:45.206 --> 00:14:48.030

00:14:48.030 --> 00:14:54.674

00:27:00.190 --> 00:27:04.530

users exceeding the quota limit and you

00:27:27.600 --> 00:27:31.030
Why do you have to check that if you're

00:27:31.030 --> 00:27:33.490
to control how much space they can use.

00:27:33.490 --> 00:27:36.170

00:27:36.170 --> 00:27:39.880
each user is actually using before

549
00:27:56.870 --> 00:28:00.830
Now a couple limitations with the NTFS
disk quotas that we need to be aware of.

550
00:28:00.830 --> 00:28:02.390
It is on a per-drive basis.

551
00:28:02.390 --> 00:28:05.630
That means if there's four different

00:28:05.630 --> 00:28:07.580
can connect to, it tallies it all up.

553
00:28:07.580 --> 00:28:10.960
If you have two files on one share,
five files on another share,

554
00:28:10.960 --> 00:28:14.850
it's adding all that space up and
it's all counting towards your quota, so

555
00:28:14.850 --> 00:28:17.820
it's per drive, not per share.

556
00:28:19.070 --> 00:28:19.990
All right.

557
00:28:19.990 --> 00:28:23.030
Other limitations here, well,
let's go through how we set this up.

00:28:23.030 --> 00:28:27.740
I can choose limit the disk space to,

00:28:27.740 --> 00:28:31.920
we'll say 1024,

00:28:34.470 --> 00:28:35.010
All right.

Or, I guess I could just simplify that and

00:28:39.370 --> 00:28:45.320
And I can set a warning to maybe,

that a user is reaching their quota.

The big limitation of this system

All right?

569

They're not checking the event log system,

most likely our users

They're not gonna know

That's a huge issue in

00:29:11.060 --> 00:29:14.890
So again, another reason these

575
00:29:14.890 --> 00:29:18.830
You can see here, I can log an event

576
00:29:18.830 --> 00:29:22.480
Log an event when they

577
00:29:22.480 --> 00:29:27.210
But again, my user's not checking their

578
00:29:27.210 --> 00:29:28.270
And that's it.

579
00:29:28.270 --> 00:29:29.070
That's all there is to it.

580
00:29:29.070 --> 00:29:30.310
I go ahead and click Apply, and

581

it's gonna warn me that if this disk

This process could take a little while

00:29:43.270 --> 00:29:47.120
a drive that's in use you might not

586
00:29:47.120 --> 00:29:47.830
I'll go ahead and click okay.

587
00:29:47.830 --> 00:29:52.760
Okay, there's really nothing on that
drive at this point, all right?

588
00:29:52.760 --> 00:29:57.270
Another big limitation
of this NTFS disk quota

00:29:57.270 --> 00:30:01.820
system is that,
again it's a per-drive basis, and

00:30:01.820 --> 00:30:07.120
also, it's based on the owner, so

I guess they're all based on owner.

00:30:18.030 --> 00:30:22.390

00:30:22.390 --> 00:30:26.820
I can change ownership if I had full

597
00:30:26.820 --> 00:30:28.660

598
00:30:28.660 --> 00:30:33.400
Another limitation is it's based on

599
00:30:33.400 --> 00:30:37.810
size used on disk, in other words, let's

600

I decide, you know what I've got these

00:30:40.910 --> 00:30:45.050
I'm gonna compress them using

00:30:45.050 --> 00:30:48.780

Depending on the type of a document, if

00:30:52.130 --> 00:30:56.750
those things and make them take less

00:30:56.750 --> 00:30:58.500
Doesn't help you towards your quota.

606
00:30:58.500 --> 00:31:02.620
Even though you free up that disk space by

00:31:02.620 --> 00:31:06.750
to say, nope, you've reached your

608
00:31:06.750 --> 00:31:09.330
Another big issue I have

00:31:10.370 --> 00:31:13.370

616
00:31:34.040 --> 00:31:38.080
So there we go, you can see the built-in

617
00:31:38.080 --> 00:31:40.180
system gets a free pass.

618
00:31:40.180 --> 00:31:43.700
Probably a good thing, you don't wanna

619
00:31:43.700 --> 00:31:48.450
I happen to be in the local admins group,

620

If I wanted to set individual quotas,

00:31:59.560 --> 00:32:04.910
I can come in here and create new entries,

And I could say you know what,
I'm gonna give him two gigabytes and

00:32:09.000 --> 00:32:13.270
I'll change his warning to 1 gigabyte or
something like that.

626
00:32:13.270 --> 00:32:16.960
We could probably find a better number but
for now that will work, so

627
00:32:16.960 --> 00:32:19.710
you can create individual entries.

628
00:32:19.710 --> 00:32:22.350
The one on the properties
affects everybody,

629
00:32:22.350 --> 00:32:27.260
except the administrators group, and in
here you can control individuals like you

630
00:32:27.260 --> 00:32:32.040
see Dan now has two gigabytes
with a one gigabyte warning.

631
00:32:32.040 --> 00:32:34.430
And that's really disk
quotas in a nutshell.

632
00:32:34.430 --> 00:32:37.300
Like I said, that there's better options
that you're going to learn about when we

00:32:37.300 --> 00:32:42.790
get into our server classes, but for
controlling access on like say a client

634
00:32:42.790 --> 00:32:48.280
machine, that's a shared computer between

635
00:32:48.280 --> 00:32:49.590
In a work group environment,

636

in a SoHo something like that,

637
00:32:52.260 --> 00:32:54.340
So it is important we
understand that they are there,

638
00:32:54.340 --> 00:32:56.310
they are available and how they work.

639
00:32:56.310 --> 00:32:56.960
>> Excellent.

640
00:32:56.960 --> 00:32:59.850
Disk quotas, NTFS permissions, hopefully,

00:33:03.180 --> 00:33:05.620

10 operating system.

00:33:05.620 --> 00:33:07.720

You have the power,

[LAUGH] Mike, is there anything else we

>> No, I think we covered

I really appreciate those demonstrations

encrypting file system, and to get there,

40

41
00:02:02.110 --> 00:02:04.950
So first off, we need to understand
there's two different types of encryption

42
00:02:04.950 --> 00:02:06.430
that we're gonna deal with here.

43
00:02:06.430 --> 00:02:10.217
There's symmetric encryption and
there's asymmetric encryption.

44
00:02:10.217 --> 00:02:14.261
And the short of it is, with symmetric
encryption you've got your algorithm, and

45
00:02:14.261 --> 00:02:17.760
then you've got a key that's
used along with that algorithm.

46
00:02:17.760 --> 00:02:22.010
And the key that you
use to encrypt the data

47
00:02:22.010 --> 00:02:25.760
is the same you use to decrypt the data.

48
00:02:25.760 --> 00:02:26.630
That's symmetric.

49
00:02:26.630 --> 00:02:28.150
The same on both sides.

50
00:02:28.150 --> 00:02:30.898
In other words, if I encrypt the document
using a symmetric algorithm,

51
00:02:30.898 --> 00:02:32.031
I'm going to generate a key.

52
00:02:32.031 --> 00:02:35.573
I'm gonna use that key with
the algorithm to encrypt the document.

53
00:02:35.573 --> 00:02:38.050
I'm gonna send that
document over to Daniel.

54
00:02:38.050 --> 00:02:40.500
Daniel is gonna need to
know what algorithm I used

55
00:02:40.500 --> 00:02:42.870
as well as have access
to the key that I used.

56
00:02:42.870 --> 00:02:45.846
Because the same key that
encrypts it also decrypts it.

57
00:02:45.846 --> 00:02:47.340
And there's a problem with that.

58
00:02:47.340 --> 00:02:51.460
The problem is if somebody intercepts that
encrypted document that I sent to Daniel,

59
00:02:51.460 --> 00:02:56.250
and intercepts the key as I send it to
Daniel they can then decrypt that document

60
00:02:56.250 --> 00:02:59.930
as well, cuz they've got the encrypted
document, they've got the key, and

61
00:02:59.930 --> 00:03:02.110
we've lost our confidentiality.

62
00:03:03.130 --> 00:03:04.510
Asymmetric encryption,

63
00:03:04.510 --> 00:03:09.930
asymmetric not the same on both sides,
we are gonna be using two different keys.

64
00:03:09.930 --> 00:03:12.869
We have what we call a public key and
a private key.

65
00:03:12.869 --> 00:03:15.609
It's also known as
public key cryptography.

66
00:03:15.609 --> 00:03:17.940
That is where that term comes from and

67
00:03:17.940 --> 00:03:21.096
the way that works is with
the two different keys,

68
00:03:21.096 --> 00:03:26.600
one of the keys will do the encryption,
the other key is gonna do the decryption.

69
00:03:26.600 --> 00:03:29.550
And it really doesn't matter
which one you use in general.

70
00:03:29.550 --> 00:03:32.200
I'll talk about which ones you're
going to use here in a minute.

71
00:03:32.200 --> 00:03:35.030
But it doesn't really matter if for
simplicity's sake,

72
00:03:35.030 --> 00:03:36.730
if we look at it just in general.

73
00:03:36.730 --> 00:03:41.940
If I use my public key to encrypt it,
the only key that can decrypt it

74
00:03:41.940 --> 00:03:45.180
is the other half of the key pair or
my private key.

75
00:03:45.180 --> 00:03:47.430
I can't use the public key encrypts it.

76
00:03:47.430 --> 00:03:49.270
I can't use the public
key to get it back out.

77
00:03:49.270 --> 00:03:51.240
I have to have the other key.

78
00:03:51.240 --> 00:03:52.190
I could do it the other way around.

79
00:03:52.190 --> 00:03:55.520
I could encrypt it with my private key,
and then the only key

80
00:03:55.520 --> 00:03:59.600
that could decrypt it would be the public
key, the other half of that key pair.

81
00:03:59.600 --> 00:04:03.000
These keys are known as a key pair,
they're mathematically related and

82
00:04:03.000 --> 00:04:07.240
they work together, and what's really cool
about this system is I don't have to worry

83
00:04:07.240 --> 00:04:12.080
about sending the key because now if I'm
gonna send Daniel an encrypted document,

84
00:04:12.080 --> 00:04:15.370
what I'm gonna do is I'm gonna ask him for
his public key, I'm gonna say,

85
00:04:15.370 --> 00:04:17.400
Daniel, give me your certificate.

86
00:04:17.400 --> 00:04:21.125
Your public key is actually part of
a certificate, and the name public should

87
00:04:21.125 --> 00:04:24.929
let you know that you don't care who has
your public key, anybody can have it.

88
00:04:24.929 --> 00:04:28.180
So I'm gonna say, Daniel, give me your
public key, I wanna encrypt something and

89
00:04:28.180 --> 00:04:29.130
send it to you.

90
00:04:29.130 --> 00:04:32.820
He'll just say, sure, here's my
certificate, and use my public key.

91
00:04:32.820 --> 00:04:37.370
If I use his public key to encrypt it,
we just learn that the only key that could

92
00:04:37.370 --> 00:04:41.580
decrypt it is the other half of
the key pair, or his private key.

93
00:04:41.580 --> 00:04:44.550
And Daniel,
if he's doing his job right, nobody,

94
00:04:44.550 --> 00:04:46.870
except Daniel has that private key.

95
00:04:46.870 --> 00:04:48.680
Hence, the name private.

96
00:04:48.680 --> 00:04:50.670
So I can encrypt it with this public key,
and

97
00:04:50.670 --> 00:04:52.880
then I could post
the document to the Internet.

98
00:04:52.880 --> 00:04:54.030
Anybody could have it.

99
00:04:54.030 --> 00:04:58.450
Because the only person that has the key
to decrypt it, is Daniel himself.

100

A lot of companies you know

So now there's only one

rtr01/sales [COUGH]
and

All right?

00:29:46.070 --> 00:29:50.500
Now, that was one person

00:29:56.460 --> 00:29:58.650

581
00:29:58.650 --> 00:30:00.234

00:30:00.234 --> 00:30:05.690

00:30:05.690 --> 00:30:06.760
Let us make this a little bigger.

00:30:10.350 --> 00:30:11.680
All right.

00:30:11.680 --> 00:30:14.240
And as I go through here.

00:30:14.240 --> 00:30:17.870
Tim, Tim, Tim, Tim, Tim,

00:30:17.870 --> 00:30:21.526
Tim, Tim, Tim, Tim, Tim,

00:30:21.526 --> 00:30:24.080
There was a System.

The point of this is,

00:30:25.980 --> 00:30:29.390
you really have to be careful about

591
00:30:29.390 --> 00:30:33.060
If you just think I'm gonna audit

00:30:42.830 --> 00:30:45.850
And hundreds of thousands of documents and
things like that.

595
00:30:45.850 --> 00:30:48.210
You can generate some huge log files.

596
00:30:48.210 --> 00:30:53.210
Not that they're big disk wise, but trying

597
00:30:53.210 --> 00:30:56.350

598
00:30:56.350 --> 00:30:59.950
So you really wanna think about
what it is that you're auditing.

599
00:30:59.950 --> 00:31:03.910
And that's auditing, there's other

00:31:03.910 --> 00:31:06.950

601
00:31:06.950 --> 00:31:09.070
It's just keeping track

00:31:09.070 --> 00:31:12.620

>> Yeah, looking for

So stick with those,

00:31:52.260 --> 00:31:53.810

00:31:53.810 --> 00:31:54.580
Great stuff, Mike.

00:31:54.580 --> 00:31:57.200
Obviously, this is security.

I mean, this is what we do to keep

621
00:32:02.140 --> 00:32:03.710
So, you need to understand these concepts.

622
00:32:03.710 --> 00:32:06.130
You need to get this under the hat,
under the belt.

623
00:32:06.130 --> 00:32:07.690
Whatever the case you wanna call it.

624
00:32:07.690 --> 00:32:12.450
So, that when you go to apply for jobs or

626
00:32:14.990 --> 00:32:17.260
Mike, have we forgotten anything for

627
00:32:17.260 --> 00:32:19.080
>> No,
I think we covered it pretty thoroughly.

628
00:32:19.080 --> 00:32:20.150
>> Excellent.

629
00:32:20.150 --> 00:32:23.450
Well, looks like we've come to the end

630
00:32:23.450 --> 00:32:24.720
Hopefully you've guys have enjoyed it.

631
00:32:24.720 --> 00:32:25.830
Thanks for watching.

632
00:32:25.830 --> 00:32:27.140
Signing off for ITProTV.

633
00:32:27.140 --> 00:32:28.790

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel explain how to configure remote connections in the Windows 10 operating system. They show you how to take advantage of the Remote Desktop program, the built-in Virtual Private Network (VPN) client, and broadband tethering.

1

Remote access is part and

If you're any kind of user, even just

21
00:01:01.370 --> 00:01:03.540
I know when I worked in

I took full advantage

23
00:01:06.405 --> 00:01:08.461
And Mike you're gonna show

00:01:08.461 --> 00:01:10.258
how to actually take

26

One of the things for a corporation,

All right.

47

48
00:02:23.190 --> 00:02:24.640

49

50
00:02:27.210 --> 00:02:29.720

00:02:29.720 --> 00:02:33.350
On the exam I don't know that they

00:02:33.350 --> 00:02:36.720
mentally I think it is good

53
00:02:36.720 --> 00:02:39.905

54
00:02:39.905 --> 00:02:40.483

55
00:02:40.483 --> 00:02:44.333
So I might be sitting at my machine at

00:02:45.670 --> 00:02:46.520
Right?

58
00:02:46.520 --> 00:02:48.880
I'm not adding it to the domain or

59
00:02:48.880 --> 00:02:52.670
I'm taking over a machine that
already exists on the network.

60
00:02:52.670 --> 00:02:57.120

61
00:02:57.120 --> 00:02:59.810

00:02:59.810 --> 00:03:01.650

only one person actively

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel walk you through accessing applications through the Azure cloud service with Azure RemoteApp. They show you how to prepare a deployment and configure the settings for RemoteApp. Then they show you how to prepare the client device to connect and use RemoteApp. Also discussed is setting security for signed apps through group policy.

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Daniel describe how to configure a Recovery Drive in Windows 10. They also show you how to setup Windows 10 to utilize Restore Points to revert a PC back to a previous state when encountering critical system issues. They also show you how to employ the Refresh and Recycle settings as recovery options.
